It was said: Sa'd al-Din Pasha, brother of As'ad Pasha, received the rank of Vizierate, and a Tugh (standard) came to him. The notables of Damascus hurried to congratulate his brother As'ad Pasha. The first of them to congratulate the Pasha was Fathi Effendi, Defterdar of Damascus. When the Pasha saw him, he stood up and entered the treasury corridor. He followed him and sat with him. As'ad Pasha took out a copy of a petition and showed it to him. Fathi Effendi took it and read it, and lo, it contained the order to kill him.
His Excellency the Pasha said to him: What do you say to this? He said: Hearing and obedience. But I am under your protection, take whatever money you want and release me. The Pasha said to him: Woe to you, traitor, I have not forgotten what you did to my uncle's women. Then he ordered lifting his sash and cutting off his head. A rope was put around his neck, he was dragged outside the Saraya, his head was cut off, and sent to the State. Then the Pasha ordered his corpse to be paraded in all the streets, roads, and alleys of Damascus for three days. This was done to him; he was paraded naked, exposed body, and they left him for the dogs. Then his corpse was buried in the cemetery of Sheikh Arslan. The Pasha ordered surrounding his house and money and arresting his aides. They arrested his Khazindar Uthman and his son, and he ordered their imprisonment. Then they brought his biggest aide, nicknamed Al-Afsa, and his head was cut off immediately. They increased the search for his aides, so some of his aides and servants were killed. Then the Vizier seized his estate and the money of all his followers for the Sublime State. It amounted to a great deal. The rest scattered like the hands of Saba (totally dispersed), as if they never were, and a state ended as if it was a phantom of imagination.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
The historian Al-Budayri said: That is for what his hands earned. He was unjust, tyrannical, hateful to the people of Damascus, wanting oppression and injustice for them, not respecting the great or the small, except people of evil, who are from the party of Satan, whom he took as equipment for every aggression.
I summarize the verification of his matter and the news of the story of seizing him, I, the poor one, refiner of history and editor of these papers, so I say:
Al-Muradi mentioned at the end of the biography of the mentioned Fathi the Defterdar, in summary: The subject of the biography used to be consulted in affairs even by Viziers and Grand Viziers. His state lasted long and Allah's favor upon him was great. His fame spread, his rank rose, and his mention was disseminated. But he used to undertake overreaching in his words and deeds. His followers were famous for corruption, immorality, drinking wine, and violating sanctities. He was also open with injustices, indifferent to the supplication of the oppressed, not avoiding harm and aggression, and was attributed to drinking wine also and other things.
Therefore, his peers and others wanted him to fall into perils. When Vizier Sulayman Pasha al-Azm, Governor of Damascus and Amir al-Hajj, died, and the order came from the State to seize his wealth and estate, the subject was attributed to [certain] matters. In the meantime, his nephew Vizier As'ad Pasha al-Azm, who was ruler in Hama, assumed governance of Damascus and Emirate of Hajj. He harbored resentment against the subject for his action attributed to him at the death of his uncle, but showed him only what pleased him.
The subject was affiliated with the Yerliya Ojak (corps). The Ojak at that time had established powers and its armies were surging with corruption. They were a league and crowds to whom the greatest hero would submit with humiliation and submissiveness. They annihilated people of honor, violated sanctities, and permitted prohibitions. They continued increasing until their corruption pervaded the lands and servants. Their leaders were a stray group and a rebellious faction, and the subject of the biography, Fathi Effendi, bestowed his favors upon them and granted them his benevolence and gifts. They were his core and delegations, having taken him as a pillar and support. The people of intellect in Damascus were in worry, distress, fear, and caution, each of them confused about his affair and fearing this situation and the consequences of his evil.
The Amir al-Hajj at that time, the Governor of Damascus As'ad Pasha mentioned, was looking at this situation, confused by those conditions; because the wretch among them would come to the Saraya prison and take out whomever he wanted of the prisoners without anyone's permission, publicly and forcefully. If the mentioned Vizier passed by them while they were sitting, they would not turn to him nor stand for him from their seats when he passed them. Rather, they would speak about him with what is inappropriate within his hearing, so he bore their detestable acts and had no choice but silence.
Their affair continued like that, until he wrote about them to the Sublime State. The order arrived to kill and annihilate them. The Vizier hid it for a while, then after that revealed it, and began killing and annihilating them. Allah gave him victory, and distresses were relieved from Damascus.
Then after a few months, the mentioned Vizier wrote to the Sublime State regarding the subject of the biography and what he was upon. He sent the papers concerning him with Ali Bey, servant (Kul) of Ahmad Pasha. That was by the arrangement of Khalil Effendi al-Siddiqi and the notables of Damascus. Then it coincided that the Grand Vizier (Sahib al-Dawla) was Hasan Pasha. He used to hate the subject Fathi because when the relative of the mentioned Hasan Pasha came, who was Ahmad Agha, the Agha of the Janissary Ojak, he expelled him, and he finally became a Vizier. So he introduced his conditions to the Sultan, and informed him in accordance with As'ad Pasha's correspondence. As'ad Pasha had guaranteed his estate to the State for a thousand purses, so the news of his killing came.
Before that, a petition had been made by the people of Damascus regarding him, but it was of no avail as he was in Istanbul, so the petition was given to him. When he came to Damascus, he began bringing it out and taking revenge on those whose names were written in it. The reason for that was the existence of the Agha of the Abode of Felicity (Dar al-Sa'ada), Bashir Agha. The subject was affiliated with him, and the mentioned Agha had supervision and protection over the subject. The destined matter coincided that Bashir Agha died, and the decree came and its time arrived. So the order to kill him came, and he was killed the worst killing in the manner we presented, and at the date we mentioned.
Al-Budayri, the author of the original, composed these Mawaliya regarding the incident of the mentioned Fathi the Defterdar, saying:
Oh what Fathi did when he became Defterdar ... His time deceived him and his luck turned around his house.
The wheel of his glory danced, O people, when it turned ... He did not consider that this time is treacherous.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
Despite what he had of bad deeds, he had good deeds and benefit for people at some times. Among his monuments is the Madrasa in Al-Qaymariyya, and he endowed stipends and soup for students of knowledge. He paved the Salihiyya road, and built the bath in Maydan al-Hasa named after him, and the coffeehouse as well. Among his greatest monuments is his renovation of the two minarets of the Sulaymaniyya Takiyya in Al-Marja, after their fall during the earthquake, so they were restored better than they were, and he has other things. However, his bad deeds were more than his good deeds. We ask Allah to cover us with His kindness and pardon, and save us from the disgrace of the world and the punishment of the Hereafter, for He is Near, Responsive, Amen.
In those days, they brought the Sheikh of Jayrud. He informed As'ad Pasha that he killed a person. The Pasha asked him, so he answered and said: He killed my father, so I killed him. He ordered his killing, so he was killed immediately.
On Sunday, the thirteenth of Rajab of the mentioned year, Muhammad Agha Ibn al-Dayri passed away from dysentery. He had witnessed the deeds of As'ad Pasha, the deeds of his father Isma'il Pasha, and his uncle Sulayman Pasha. He was the expense agent, but all works revolved around him, and he was the owner of the influential word with them, until it was said he was the author of every movement that occurred in Damascus, and that he committed immoralities like drinking wine and others along with harming the subjects. During the days of sedition, he used to walk in front of the Dalatiyya robbing, looting, and destroying the houses of Janissaries. He brought the stones of their houses and their wood and built a house with them. The building was not completed before he perished with the perishing, and the Pasha seized his money and property, and he went with those who went.
The day after his death, the Pasha killed Uthman Agha, Khazindar of Fathi Effendi the Defterdar as we presented, and killed with him Ahmad Agha al-Shurbaji, the second Khazindar of Fathi, and seized their money.
On this day, Monday the fourteenth of Rajab, they brought the Samarmar water. The Sheikhs and people of Tariqas went out to meet it with flags, drums, and falcon drums. They entered in a great procession in which many people wept. They hung it on the minaret of the Greatest Sheikh (Ibn Arabi) in Salihiyya, on the minaret of the Marja Takiyya, and on the minarets of the Umayyad Mosque. They kept in the Saraya skins of Samarmar water, and mentioned they intended to hang them in the lands of Hauran.
This while high prices were standing on foot and leg, the like of which did not occur in ancient times. A rotl of bread reached seven masari, medium six, and bad poor quality five masari. A rotl of cakes fifteen masari, a rotl of rice ten masari. An ounce of ghee five masari at the time of its import, an ounce of tahini five masari, an ounce of sesame oil five masari, an ounce of Qarisheh (cheese/curd) three masari. Likewise cheese and dibs, a rotl for eighteen masari. A rotl of honey for a piastre and a half. A mudd of salt reached twenty masari. A mudd of chickpeas three quarters of a masriyyah, and likewise lentils.
Stranger than that, despite the abundance of fruit, a rotl of fresh figs for four masari, zucchini three for a masriyyah, eggplant a rotl for eight masari, every pumpkin for four masari, a rotl of meat for half a piastre, a watermelon for half a quarter of a riyal, whether yellow or green, and cucumber a rotl for two masriyyahs.
This matter lasted for seven or eight years, but in this year the limit increased, and rulers did not inspect the subjects. This with lack of buying and selling, depression, abundance of debts on servants, and oppression of some by others. The vast earth narrowed upon the servants, and judgment is for Allah.
On Sunday, the twenty-first of the month of Rajab in this year one thousand one hundred and fifty-nine, His Excellency As'ad Pasha al-Azm gathered the grandees of Damascus and its notables in the court, and endowed all his properties to his children, then to his children's children according to what he stipulated in the endowment deed. He distributed to his cousins what was theirs. He had seized the money of Muhammad Agha Ibn al-Dayri and calculated it according to his mind, so it appeared to His Excellency As'ad Pasha that twelve purses remained for him with the mentioned Ibn al-Dayri. Then the guilds came and informed His Excellency the Pasha that they had remaining dues with Ibn al-Dayri from the days of your father Isma'il Pasha and your uncle Sulayman Pasha. And in the days of your rule twelve thousand piastres, and they persisted in demanding it. He said: Follow him and take them from him, for I have remaining with him twelve purses of gold, so there is no benefit for you in this request. Each of them left his money with Allah and went.
On the eve of Friday, the twenty-fifth of the month of Rajab, As'ad Pasha went out to the Dawra (tour) of this year. On the eve of Tuesday, the twenty-ninth of the month of Rajab of this year, Mustafa Effendi Zade, Judge of Damascus, passed away, and his son became deputy in his place.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On Friday, the twenty-second of the month of Sha'ban of this year, Muhammad Agha bin Farrukh arrived with the position of Defterdar of Damascus, replacing Fathi Effendi al-Falaqinsi, and resided in his house famous by them.
During these days, worry increased for people and the stagnation of conditions intensified with severe high prices. Bread was six masari as we presented, until a head of cabbage the size of a bitter orange became two masriyyahs, and the rest in this manner. The matter belongs to Allah, the King, the Exalted.
During these days of this year, the decree of Tripoli of Syria came to His Excellency Sa'd al-Din Pasha. He was with his brother in the Dawra, so he returned with his brother to Damascus, stayed a little, and marched seeking his position, may Allah grant him success.
In this year, the confirmation of Ramadan was on the eve of Monday, Eid on Wednesday, and fasting was complete.
On Friday after prayer, the seventh of Shawwal of this year, His Excellency the Governor of Damascus and Amir al-Hajj As'ad Pasha al-Azm left intending the Noble Hajj. The Hajj left on the twentieth. When His Excellency the Pasha traveled, he left the Mutasallim there, who was Musa Kikhiya, in his place in Damascus. News reached him that the Zarbawat, who are the expelled wretches, intended to come to Damascus while its people were unaware, and kill a group of those who caused their expulsion. The mentioned Mutasallim was disturbed, and sent to fetch Abdullah the Turk, Agha of the Dalatiyya who was expelled, strengthened his power, and increased his group. Mahmoud Agha, Agha of the Tafakjiya Dalatiyya, began patrolling and roaming at night outside Damascus, and the Dalatiyya hovered around the city. They disturbed the people and distress increased. This situation continued for the duration of the Pasha's and Hajj's absence.

Year 1160
Then the year one thousand one hundred and sixty entered. Its first Muharram was Thursday. On Monday, the fifth of Muharram al-Haram of this year, corresponding to the first of Kanun al-Thani (January), waters rose due to a great torrent. Its entry into Damascus was at midnight. A flood occurred the like of which had not been heard since ancient times. The water attacked Damascus from midnight, and drowned all shops in its path, and destroyed much wealth that cannot be counted or reckoned, until Al-Marja became like the sea. With that, the water snatched birds, and had a murmuring, buzzing, and roaring. This increase covered the date stone of the Citadel, passed through markets and houses, and brought out unconfined things. It became under the Citadel and in Al-Manakh at the height of a man's stature.
The historian Al-Budayri said: I entered the Manakhiliyya coffeehouse after the water receded and found the water on its highest benches higher than a cubit. The old and young turned gray from its terror. Unconfined people drowned in it, besides what was destroyed of animals and wealth. It harmed everything it passed over, and many uncountable places collapsed and were left as ruins. We ask Allah Almighty for kindness in what is destined, Amen.
On the fifth of Safar was the arrival of the Noble Hajj. The pilgrims reported that this year was one of the most beautiful and best years. All of them were thankful and praying for His Excellency As'ad Pasha continuously, due to the abundant comfort, good, and favors they received on the road from His Excellency the Pasha for all pilgrims. May Allah reward him with the best reward, Amen.
Bakir Shah, Governor of Jeddah, arrived with As'ad Pasha from Hijaz in this year. He stayed in the house of Fathi Effendi mentioned before for about two months in Damascus, then marched intending Hama, and the reason for his coming was not known.
The Sheikh al-Islam also returned with the Syrian caravan, stayed a while in Damascus, and marched seeking Istanbul. He was an elderly, dignified man, who did not move a motionless object in Damascus during his stay. After the arrival of the Hajj, the Treasury of Egypt [arrived] to Damascus, having been delayed from its appointment.
His Excellency As'ad Pasha intensified the search after his return from Hajj for the Zarb wretches. They arrested Amin Ibn al-Hadid and Abduh bin Hamza Anbar. He ordered their killing, so they were killed the worst killing.
The Dalatiyya increased aggression and injustice, and ruined lands and villages. Complaints about them increased to the Governor of Damascus As'ad Pasha. He wrote to the State against them regarding their affair. A decree came to him to annihilate them. So he ordered a crier to call out that any of the Dalatiyya who stays in Damascus more than three days, from the people of corruption and obstinacy, his blood is shed with impunity. Then after days, the Dalatiyya appeared and the matter was not completed. Judgment is for Allah, Knower of the hidden.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On Wednesday, news came that the Anaza Arabs looted the Rasha Arabs, and that the Kurds who were with the Anaza Arabs took all they had looted and robbed of wealth, camels, sheep, and women. The sheep were numerous, their number counted only by Allah. The incident was terrifying, and many were killed from both sides. The helper of the Arabs was His Excellency As'ad Pasha, as it was said. They brought the sheep to Damascus. The people of Damascus had been facing high meat prices and eating corn and barley for years. A rotl of meat was sold in this year for seven masari and eight to ten, with people knowing it was forbidden loot. Some refrained from eating it, and they were fewer than few, and the rest, who were the general public, did not care. To Allah we belong and to Him we return.
The historian Al-Budayri, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Locusts had hatched from the previous year in Damascus and its lands. When spring came, they began to appear little by little until they appeared in a hideous manifestation, and began crawling like ants and motes. They began eating crops and destroying plants, so people fell into great distress. His Excellency As'ad Pasha, may Allah preserve him, alerted the peasants generally to collect them and bring them. He imposed on the fifth lands (Al-Khums) two qintars for every land, and likewise villages and hamlets, each hamlet a known amount to collect. They brought loads of it and he ordered it to be buried. Some was buried in a cave near the Baramika cemetery and covered with earth. Then they began digging pits in the graves of Christians and Jews and putting it in them.
Then it continued to increase and spread. His Excellency As'ad Pasha, may Allah reward him, ordered repeating the obligation on every village of Damascus, two hundred qintars, and whoever did not bring the requirement would face a penalty. He also ordered, may Allah preserve him, some officials to record against them, and to put it in Mount Salihiyya in wells and caves.
The historian Al-Budayri said: It reached me that in three days they put in Salihiyya one thousand seven hundred qintars of locusts, besides what was put in caves and wells in other than Salihiyya.
On Monday, the last of Rabi' al-Thani of this year, news came to Damascus that the bird called Samarmar had come and passed over the village of Adra and Dumayr, and destroyed much of the locusts. The people of the country rejoiced, especially the people of Damascus. The people of Salihiyya went out, accompanied by Sheikhs, Taghaliba (drummers/Sufis?), women, men, and children, weeping and wailing and supplicating to Allah Almighty to lift this affliction and raise the high prices. Then the people of Damascus decorated in joy for the arrival of the Samarmar with the best decoration.
In these days, news spread in Damascus that there is a woman in Damascus called Al-Samawiyya who catches children by trickery, and men too, to extract poison from them. People were afraid and panic increased, and people began advising each other against her. After a few days, a clamor occurred among people. It was asked: What is the news? They said: They caught Al-Samawiyya. Behold, she was an old woman caught by the common people, with children and men behind her like locusts, beating her painfully. They went with her to the Judge. He asked her about her condition and where she came from. She said: By Allah, my master, I am a poor woman, I have children and family, and this saying about me is falsehood and slander. He said: The Judge ordered searching her and her house. They searched her and found with her toys that children play with, and in her pocket large and small skullcaps. Then they went and searched her house, and found nothing in it but old belongings and a piece of mat. Then her neighbors testified that she is a poor woman, residing in this place for a long time, and we did not know any evil state about her. Then they released her, and she went on her way.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
Then in those days locusts increased and harmed the servants, and it was as if people had collected nothing of it. All this with the increase of immorality, debauchery, delusion, high prices, and evils. Sheikh Ibrahim al-Jabawi went out with the Taghaliba with flags and drums, and intended visiting Sayyida Zaynab. They sought help there for uncovering the affliction from the servants, and returned at the end of the day. Then they circled around the city of Damascus, passed in front of the Saraya gate and performed a Dawsa (trampling ceremony), and a great state and severe weeping occurred. Lamps of the Men (Saints) of [God] were lit, while they prayed for the destruction of locusts and lifting of affliction.
After two days, the people of Al-Maydan came with drums, flags, state, and screaming, intending the Musalla Mosque, praying for lifting the locusts and their destruction. They said: O You who has the will in everything He willed, by the Beloved Chosen One relieve the lands. But that was of no avail. How can that avail when most women have become unrestrained, and daughters of passion, the sinners, roaming night and day in alleys and markets, accompanied by Dalatiyya and immoral men. No one speaks a word, no enjoining of good nor forbidding of evil. The righteous is in worry and distress, and the immoral and bad is turning in delicious bliss. O Allah relieve, Amen.
On Thursday, the eighth of Jumada al-Ula of this year, His Excellency the Pasha ordered the Janissaries in Damascus, the Za'ims, Sipahis, and ten individuals from every village to march to the Druze Mountain. He ordered ovens to be built in Al-Biqa' to bake bread. It reached us that a decree came to him that the Pasha of Sidon and Pasha of Tripoli should be with him to assist him, and ordered the Matawila to help him in fighting them.
The time was in the month of Iyyar (May), and crops were remaining in the ground, nothing harvested yet. Creation feared from those conditions, and high prices were present in Damascus, a rotl of bread from seven to eight masari.
On the eve of Thursday, the fifteenth of Jumada al-Ula of this year, As'ad Pasha al-Azm killed Sayyid Salih bin Ibrahim Bey al-Suqiyya. We asked about the reason, and it was said his father complained to the Pasha that his son Salih spoke to his father with obscene words and wanted to shoot him. His Excellency the Pasha sent and ordered his son be brought humiliated. At evening he ordered him strangled, so he was strangled and thrown, and the command is for Allah.
On Friday after prayer, His Excellency As'ad Pasha went out to Al-Marja and ordered the Damascus army of Janissaries and Za'ims to be displayed to him. Then he departed, and three days after his departure the Damascus Ojaks followed him. When he reached Al-Biqa', he destroyed some Druze villages, burned, looted, and killed. Then he raided there Arabs called Al-Furaykhat. They fought him for days, then escaped with their livestock and families, leaving tents and money, that was after they killed a group of the Pasha's soldiers and wounded [others]. We were informed they were obedient. He sent casting their cattle upon the villages and guilds, and did a deed leading to dispute. Then he camped in Al-Biqa' and ordered harvesting the Druze crops, so they harvested the yield of Al-Biqa'. High prices were increasing, and locusts in the land of Damascus increasing, but Allah bridled them as mercy to His creation.
On Thursday, the eighth of Jumada al-Thani, five days before the start of the summer forty days (Marba'aniyyat al-Sayf), there was frightening thunder and lightning, and the sky poured rain like mouths of waterskins. Days before that, there was much thunder without rain. These conditions are a lesson for those who take heed.
It reached me about His Excellency As'ad Pasha while he was in the Druze Mountain that a complaint came to him from the family of a Sunni victim against a Druze man, that he was a partner to a Turkmen man in about five hundred heads of sheep, and that the Druze assassinated his Turkmen partner and killed him. His Excellency the Pasha ordered searching for the Druze. He was captured and he ordered his killing, so he was killed. He seized the sheep he had and sent them to Damascus, where they were sold by imposition (Tarh) on the butchers of Damascus, each head for eight piastres. Those who complained, he gave them neither dirham nor dinar. To Allah is the matter.
In these days, three Jews from the city of Aleppo arrived in Damascus. They had skill in playing instruments with the best tunes. They began working in the coffeehouses of Damascus, and the elite and commoners listened to them.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
In the middle of Jumada al-Thani, it reached me that some of As'ad Pasha's soldiers, said to be Maghrebis, provoked the Druze while the Pasha and his soldiers were camping in their lands. They fired bullets at them, and skirmishes with fighting occurred. His Excellency the Pasha stood on his feet, while he was sitting for lunch, and took a spear in his hand, it was said he put on armor, and sought fighting in front of his army. He took before him the Janissaries of Damascus, led by Muhammad Agha bin Abdullah Agha Kumush Aghli. The Agha shouted at his group and sought the raid alone, and the Pasha and the rest of the army followed him. They dragged the cannons and raided earnestly seeking the mouth of the mountain. Bullets from them and on them were like rain. The first to be defeated were the Dalatiyya soldiers, people of arrogance and tyranny. No one, praise be to Allah, from the Damascus Ojak army was hit except a man from the Baalbek Janissaries.
Then His Excellency As'ad Pasha scolded the Dalatiyya soldiers after severe anger from him, and said to them: Woe to you as helpers, and to him who took you as supporters. You take fodder and money and flee from war and fighting, while volunteers fight for Allah and His Messenger, and race to war, despite what I have done to them of deeds of killing, looting, and destroying homes. But I will acknowledge this matter for them and remove evil and oppression from them. Then he called the Damascus Ojak and promised them benevolence and honor.
Then the war remained burning for the rest of that day. Then His Excellency the Pasha took the cannons to the mountain, and swore solemn oaths that he would not return from the mountain until he cast everyone in it to destruction and ruin, and make them tales [of the past]. Then he wrote to Homs, Hama, Ma'arra, and Damascus to strip for him sturdy men. He requested from every village fifteen individuals, and set for its people that each one's wage is half a piastre, and sent imposing on them some individuals, and increased on them the impositions of money. He tightened the matter on people until he constricted their breaths, and exceeded measure.
Four individuals from the elders of the mountain had been killed along with those killed that day. Despite that, they asked for peace and weighed money for him, but he refused except killing and looting. Days before the incident, His Excellency the Pasha had ordered that the crops belonging to the Druze and others be harvested and ordered seizing it. Whenever they collected something, they looted it. There were many blessings, because the yield of this year was something much, the like of which was not heard, and most of it was trampled under feet.
A rotl of bread in Damascus was six masari. When the new wheat came, they sold it for five masari. Two days later, they called out the rotl for three masari. They said: O subjects, the Lord of creation has bestowed favor upon you, a rotl of bread for three masari. The next day, bribery (Bartil) and corruption worked for the Mutasallim Musa Kikhiya and other people of injustice. Immediately they heard a crier calling that no one sells a rotl of bread for less than four masari. It was said that was from the Sheikh of Millers, nicknamed Al-Takhan; may Allah treat him with what he deserves, Amen.
The previous movement which disturbed the Pasha was caused by Allah, and the recompense is of the type of the deed, because His Excellency the Pasha had taken the hand of the mentioned Takhan, the Sheikh of Millers, and the Pasha had ordered him to sell his wheat at the price of a ghirara for thirty-five piastres. Then after the Pasha's march, which was the day of the movement, the price of wheat had gone down, so the price of a ghirara became twenty-five piastres. No one could sell at this price except secretly. The matter narrowed on the poor and needy. Anyone from the common people who moved, they tied him with a long rope, and dragged him either to torture or to killing and looting of money and honor. The command is for Allah, the High, the Great.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
The historian Al-Budayri said: It reached me about As'ad Pasha while he was descending to the Druze Mountain that he was informed that a village of Al-Biqa' belonged to the Druze. He ordered his army to loot and rob it. When they reached them, its people met them with cheer, joy, and tranquility, unaware of what was intended for them. They hosted them, slaughtered for them, and entertained them. They dismounted, ate, and had their fill. Then they rose and drew swords against them. They shouted at them: Do not do it, you are our friends and excellent guests. They did not listen but killed a group of them and wounded [others]. They sought defeat immediately and fled from their faces. They looted their belongings, jewelry, and wealth. Then they sought the women, so they fled from them, and entered some orchards there. They were more than three hundred women and virgin girls. That army attacked them, and each one of them grabbed one, while they were screaming with weeping and wailing. They found no helper until they committed the abominable with them. This was reported to me by one who witnessed the reality of this news. They burned the village after looting all that was in it and left its people in woe and exemplary punishment. Sufficient for us is Allah, and [He is] the best Disposer of affairs. That was before the incident, and it was said it was the cause of the sedition.
When His Excellency As'ad Pasha gathered the crowds and filled the deserts and quarters, among those who came to the Pasha was Muhammad Pasha of Sidon. He was an elderly man who had experienced time and its people. As'ad Pasha met him with honor and respect and complained to him about what the Druze sect did of treachery and fighting, and asked him for help in this situation. Muhammad Pasha blamed him for that, and ordered him to desist from fighting them. He said to him: This is a matter that returns on us and on you with destruction, and the State does not approve of it because they, meaning the men of the State, want prosperity for the lands and hate injustice and corruption. They are capable of sending ten viziers in one day, but they cannot populate in ten years a village if it is destroyed from these villages. For my sake also, make peace with them, take your money owed by them from the known tribute, and release their children. As'ad Pasha had imprisoned the children of their princes in the Citadel, and they had been there for more than two years, being young and not reached puberty. Then he insisted on him with that.
His Excellency As'ad Pasha answered him to that, but outwardly not inwardly, because the intention of the mentioned Pasha was to destroy them to the last one, and this is among the impossible. His Excellency As'ad Pasha said to him: You then manage this matter with your opinion. He said: Let us stipulate on them what you want of conditions. He swore to him that he would not stipulate a condition on them, nor take money, nor do anything with them.
Then Muhammad Pasha, Pasha of Sidon, bid farewell after he honored and respected him, while concealing the opposite of what he showed. It reached me that at the time he sent news to the Sublime State asking for the Vizierate in Sidon for his brother Mustafa Bey, so that he could do with the Mountain what he wanted, and heal the heart from them. It was said that the Pasha of Sidon sent asking the people of the Mountain for a sum of money for As'ad Pasha. They swore to him they would not give him even a cord (Iqal), but if he sent our children we would send him forty purses, which is customary upon us. Otherwise let him do what he wants, for by Allah if he moves a motionless object we will demolish the country upon him. For what have we done that he meets us with these matters? Is it not enough that he shed our blood and made permissible our wealth and women, and has destroyed for us more than two hundred purses of wheat and grains.
This while As'ad Pasha had dispersed what he gathered, and his eyes tearing from his rage, and matters remained under illusions. The Sipahi and Janissary Ojaks returned to Damascus, and matters and conditions were not organized. Judgment is for Allah, the King, the Exalted.
In the month of Rajab of this year, which is the year one thousand one hundred and sixty, a war occurred between Bani Sakhr and Anaza Arabs in the land of Hauran due to seizing sheep of some tribes.
In this month also, news arrived in Damascus that the Druze came down from the mountain, looted, robbed, and burned eighteen villages of the land of Al-Biqa', and besieged Baalbek and tightened the siege on it.
On Wednesday, the eighth of Rajab, Abdullah Pasha Ibn al-Kibrli arrived from Sidon. His coming was from Istanbul, and it was rumored about him that he wants Hajj. He stayed in the house of Abu Shanab.
On Monday of this month, Sheikh Abd al-Rahim bin al-Istanbuliya passed away, may Allah have mercy on him. On that day cannons were fired. I asked about the reason, it was said: Sidon came to Musa Kikhiya, Mutasallim of Damascus on behalf of As'ad Pasha. This man was first a Kikhiya under Isma'il Pasha Ibn al-Azm. A Firman came with the Kapici to prepare saddles to fight the Druze, and to tighten on them and destroy them to the last one.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On Monday, the seventh of Sha'ban of this year, His Excellency As'ad Pasha ordered the Dalatiyya and Atliyya to ride and raid the land of Al-Biqa' and those in it of the Druze, to kill, capture, loot, and do what they wanted. Then it reached me that they raided a group of Druze while they were unaware, killing some of them and their Sheikhs, capturing the rest of them, looting wealth, beasts, sheep, women, and children, and came with their heads to Damascus. The day of their arrival was a day from which skins shivered with awe. We ask Him, the Exalted, to rectify conditions, have mercy on the people of Damascus, and lower prices for them.
On Thursday, the tenth of Sha'ban, Sheikh Ibrahim al-Jabawi, administrator of the Umayyad Mosque, held a wedding celebration for his grandson. He ordered markets to be decorated with lamps and candles, and ordered the minarets of the Umayyad Mosque to be lit, so they were lit. This is something we never heard had happened for another.
On the eve of Saturday, the Guardian Saint, the belief of the people of Damascus, Sheikh Imran son of Sheikh Ibrahim, Imam of the Disease of Happiness (Da' al-Sa'ada - possibly Dar al-Sa'ada?), passed away. He, may Allah have mercy on him, was of the people of spiritual states. He had six fingers on his right hand, and wrote beautiful script with his left hand imitating any script, and had a beautiful voice in reciting Quran. He was buried in Bab al-Saghir next to our master Bilal, may Allah be pleased with him.
In this year, news reached us of the death of Ahmad Pasha bin Hasan Pasha, Governor of Baghdad. It was said the cause of his death was that the State sent him a poisoned fur coat, he wore it, poison crept into his body, and he died, may Allah have mercy on him. He was, may Allah have mercy on him, brave, daring, a manager of affairs; servants obeyed him and lands submitted to him. He repelled every tyrant from Baghdad. Tahmasp the Kharijite intended him with a huge army, besieged Baghdad for months but could not conquer it, so he returned humiliated and small, and sought the land of India and Tatars. He set his son upon him who killed and destroyed him. His son took over his place, did not rebel against the State, and his name was Dabbus.
When Ahmad Pasha, Governor of Baghdad, died, the State sent a governor to Baghdad, Kor Muhammad Pasha, who was a former Grand Vizier. When he settled in Baghdad, the Janissaries asked him for 'Ala'if', meaning salaries. He said to them: Your salaries are with me. They said: No, Ahmad Pasha who was before you used to give it to us from his own money, and when it came to him from the State he would take it. He said to them: I will not do that. They said: It must be so, and they were harsh with him in speech, and they were like a raging sea. He said: If it must be so, send to me from your leaders from every town three men, to receive the money. They did so. When they arrived at his place, he ordered killing them and throwing their bodies. When they saw that, they rushed to the Citadel and fired at it with cannons and gunpowder, until they demolished his Saraya, and killed the Agha of his group. The Pasha exited from a tunnel underground leading outside the city and fled escaping to the land of Persia. Then the people of Baghdad wrote to the Sublime State to send a governor to Baghdad for them whom they named for it, who was with his master Ahmad Pasha the aforementioned, and had complete preparedness. So they sent him to them and they were pleased with him.
On the twenty-seventh of Sha'ban, As'ad Pasha arrived from the Dawra. His entry was around Maghrib Adhan. Many Maghrebis came with him.
In this year, the confirmation of Ramadan was Wednesday. Cannons were fired that night at the fifth hour, and some Imams prayed Tarawih that night. A ghirara of wheat became twenty piastres. Allah help us with this high price, which is a rotl of bread for five masari, rice for eleven masari, and eggplant for four masari.
On the eighth of Ramadan, the Sheikh al-Islam came from Istanbul intending Hajj to the Sacred House of Allah. The notables of Damascus went out to meet him. He stayed twelve days, and passed away to Allah's mercy. His grave became in Damascus, buried in Bab al-Saghir south of our master Bilal, may Allah be pleased with him.
On Tuesday, the twenty-first of the month of Ramadan, As'ad Pasha alerted that the Riyal be two piastres less a third. It was first a piastre and a half and four masari. Eid al-Fitr in this year was on Friday.
On Saturday, the sixteenth of Shawwal, the Noble Mahmal left accompanied by Amir al-Hajj As'ad Pasha al-Azm, may Allah preserve him. He set up Musa Kikhiya mentioned before as deputy for him in Damascus as Mutasallim. A noble decree came after the Pasha's departure to Hajj to release the Druze children from the Citadel. The Mutasallim released them, and there was great joy in the Mountain. Had As'ad Pasha been in Damascus, he would not have released them, because orders had come to him often to release them but he did not release them.
In this year, rain is little and high prices much. The main food of the people of Damascus was corn and barley bread. The poor have no helper or supporter besides Allah.

Year 1161

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
Then entered the year one thousand one hundred and sixty-one. Its first was Muharram Tuesday. Villages were ruined by the oppression of the Dalatiyya, and their unsatisfactory deeds.
The historian Al-Budayri said: In Muharram, our Sheikh and lover Sheikh Muhammad al-Masri al-Azhari nicknamed Abu al-Surur passed away. He was buried in Marj al-Dahdah near the river in a paved grave with two markers. He, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, was a virtuous religious scholar. Among his virtues is that no one met him without obtaining joy and happiness, even if he did not speak. This is the greatest proof of the goodness of his inner self.
On Saturday, the twenty-sixth of Muharram, the Jukhadar of Hajj came, and announced that this year has no equal in cheapness and prosperity. On the fifth of Safar, the Hajj writer came and reported that the Hajj is delayed due to much snow and rain. On the eve of Tuesday of Safar al-Khayr, the Hajj entered at night. The next day, Sunday, the Amir al-Hajj As'ad Pasha and his brother Sa'd al-Din Pasha, Amir of Tripoli of Syria, entered. The pilgrims received every good in this year, and saw no disturber except a torrent that came to them while in Badr, which destroyed and drowned. In the station of Al-Ula, snow, rain, and hail fell, causing hardship for the Hajj, but with great kindness.
During the absence of the Hajj, a report confirming As'ad Pasha in Damascus arrived.
On Thursday, the seventeenth of Safar, Sheikh Ahmad authorized us to read every day after Fajr prayer after sending blessings on the Prophet, peace be upon him: 'Ya Aziz' (O Mighty) eighty-seven times. He informed that its properties are great, and that if a person supplicates after it with what he loves, his supplication is answered.
On the twenty-second of Safar al-Khayr, the Treasury of Egypt arrived in Damascus. High prices intensified in Damascus, until a rotl of meat became thirty masari, a rotl of rice twelve masari, and bread a rotl for five, six, and seven masari, everyone selling by his opinion.
At the end of Rabi' al-Awwal of this year, the ruler of Damascus As'ad Pasha announced regarding flus (copper coins) every nine for a masriyyah, and silver masari every thirty-six for a piastre.
On Sunday, the second of Rabi' al-Thani, Muhammad Agha Ibn al-Zarkhali, the Arabic scribe in Tripoli, was killed. He was with Sa'd al-Din Pasha, Governor of Tripoli, in the Jarda. When he returned and reached Damascus, As'ad Pasha ordered him raised to the Citadel. After days, he ordered his killing, so he was killed, and his sin was not known.
On Tuesday, the last of Jumada al-Thani of this year, sedition occurred between the Ashraf and the Kapikulu. The reason for that was that a Sharif man bought a pistol from a Sharif man and wanted to test it. He came to the moat to test it. When he fired it, the Agha of the Kapikulu heard its sound, and he was sleeping, so he woke up terrified, and said: Bring me the one who shoots with this rifle. His aides came and arrested him and a group with him. They took them to their Agha, who ordered each of them to be lashed three hundred times. They were beaten painfully and left like dead. Then they put their sashes in their underwear. What was done to them reached the Naqib of Ashraf; so he sent and brought them to his house. The second day, the Ashraf rose on foot and leg, and attacked the Kapikulu and fought. Three of the Ashraf were killed, many wounded, and the whole city closed.
On the third day, a council was held at As'ad Pasha's, ruler of Damascus. The notables gathered in it like the Mufti, Naqib, and scholars. Then the council ended, and they ruled against the Kapikulu to give the blood money of the martyr Ashraf to their heirs. Then the Pasha ordered markets to be opened and livelihood sought.
On the day of the incident, two of the Ashraf, the first called Sayyid Hasan, Sheikh of the youth of Bab al-Musalla, and the second Sayyid Muhammad bin al-Dahhan from al-Sinaniyya, had attacked with their sticks and assaulted the Kapikulu, driving them back to the Citadel losers. Two days later, on Saturday after Asr, while Sayyid Muhammad bin al-Dahhan was passing in Al-Qanawat, a person from the Kapikulu group shot him with a pistol, hitting him in his stomach. The Ashraf and people of the city rose and attacked As'ad Pasha informing him of the news. He said to them: If he dies I kill his adversary, otherwise I will manage him. The shot man died after Dhuhr. The Ashraf went to the Pasha, who ordered bringing witnesses to judge the killer. They went for witnesses, but no one agreed to testify against the killer. They said: Who testifies to be killed, when his opponent is about five thousand wretch thugs. In short, they did not prove the claim, and left the blood of the Ashraf to go in vain. The command is for Allah, the High, the Great.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
These Kapikulu, a Sultanic order and Noble Decree had come regarding them to abolish them from Damascus, and that whoever employs or returns them is cursed son of cursed. But the ruler at that time became certain that the city would not be right except with them, so he confirmed and kept them. Afterward, the Kapikulu started saying: The killing of a Sharif is worth an Akhshaya of silver. Judgment is for Allah, and zeal is for Allah and His Messenger.
The next day, Friday, As'ad Pasha held a council, gathering in it the scholars and notables of Damascus, and said to them: Tonight I am traveling on the Dawra, so take charge of the city and do not let anyone transgress against anyone. They said: O our Effendi, we are people, some scholars, some poor, some teachers, and our craft is reading books. He said to them: This is your admission, so how are you the Notables (A'yan)? They said: God forbid, the Notables of Damascus are only the Kapikulu. He said to them: This is your admission, and you have verified that its Notables and Protectors are the Kapikulu. At that point, he sent for the heads of the Kapikulu and handed the city to them. That was cunning from him. Then he traveled and left people turning in the bed of oppression and distress.
A man from the Ashraf was among those who, during the days of their sedition, opened his shop after things calmed down. While he was opening his shop, a group of Kapikulu arrested him and raised him to the Citadel, after tying him firmly and loading him with chains, as if he were of the Jews or the people of Aad and Thamud. Then they searched for others to join him, so most Ashraf fled. Look, O Muslims, at this justice, and say: O Hidden of Kindnesses save us from what we fear.
In those days, corruption increased, servants were oppressed, and daughters of passion multiplied in the markets day and night. Among what happened under As'ad Pasha's rule in these days is that one of the daughters of passion fell in love with a Turkish boy. He fell ill, so she vowed upon herself if he recovered from his illness to read a Mawlid for him at Sheikh Arslan's. After days he recovered from his illness. So she gathered the sluts of the city, the prostitutes, and they walked in the markets of Damascus carrying candles, lamps, and incense burners, singing, clapping hands, and beating tambourines. People stood in rows watching them, while they were unveiled with loose hair. There was no denier of this evil, and the righteous raised their voices saying: Allahu Akbar.
Among what happened in the blessed month of Rajab of this year is that a man married his son and held a wedding feast. At evening, he took the groom with an 'Arada (procession), candles, and drums. The aides of the Mutasallim Musa Kikhiya came out against them. The head of the ruler's aides was Mahmoud Basha al-Baghdadi, and he was invited to the feast. When they reached the middle of the market with the Arada, he was the first to assault them. All people fled; this one his Kavuk flew off, this one left his slippers, and the other his cloak was taken. The next day, the ruler ordered the arrest of the boy's father and raising him to the Citadel, and demanded a large sum of money from him. The command is for Allah, the High, the Great.
In these days, a man was slaughtered in his bed in the village of Zabdin. On Saturday, the seventeenth of Rajab, a Sharif man was slaughtered in the neighborhood of Bab al-Salam in his house, and no one was found with him. Days before that, this victim's uncle was shot by a man in Al-Darwishiyya with a pistol in his neck, slaughtering him and he died instantly. The historian said: I saw him with my own eyes thrown in the road, and they proved nothing against the killer.
On Tuesday, the ninth of Rajab, a Maghrebi entered one of the orchards wanting corruption. The owner of the orchard spoke to him nicely. The Maghrebi cursed and insulted him severely. The orchard owner was brave, so he stood up to the Maghrebi, took his gear, and tied him up. Then he feared the consequence of this matter, so he untied his bond, gave him his gear, and apologized to him. The Maghrebi did nothing but let his meanness overcome him, took his rifle and shot him with a bullet, killing him instantly. The orchard owner's brother came and hit the Maghrebi with a pistol that came to his hand. The Maghrebi wanted to flee. Men and women shouted. A boy came and hit the Maghrebi with a club throwing him to the ground. They tied him and took him to the ruler. He confessed to the killing before the ruler, and the next day they strangled him.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On Thursday, the twenty-first of Rajab, a Maghrebi hit his mother-in-law and killed her. Three days later, he killed a Christian in Al-Shaghour. This Maghrebi was the doorman of Mustafa Bey bin al-Azm, brother of As'ad Pasha, Pasha of Damascus.
On the twenty-ninth of Rajab of this year, the sun eclipsed until Damascus darkened. People saw stars as they see them at night. It remained eclipsed twenty-one degrees. People prayed the eclipse prayer in the Umayyad Mosque. The Imam leading the people was Sheikh Ahmad al-Manini, one of the preachers of the Umayyad Mosque. It reached me that at the time of the eclipse, the lamp of our neighbor, the Saint with miracles Sheikh Izz al-Din Abu Hamra, lit up, and his shrine is in his mosque known by him in Bab al-Sarija.
In those days, Arabs raided many camels in the village of Al-Qadam, and they were taken and nothing returned. Also in these days, Druze raided the village of Al-Zabadani and others, taking much livestock, goods, and other things.
On the eve of Friday, the fourteenth of Sha'ban of this year, the moon eclipsed a total eclipse, until nothing of it appeared. That was at the seventh hour of the night.
On Tuesday, the twenty-fifth of the month of Sha'ban, Sayyid Abu Bakr Mulla Khunkar arrived in Damascus intending Hajj to the Sacred House of Allah. He was the first to arrive from the distant pilgrims.
On the eve of Monday, the tenth of the blessed month of Ramadan, His Excellency the Governor of Damascus and its ruler, the Perilous Vizier As'ad Pasha al-Azm arrived from the Dawra. He was, praise be to Allah, in utmost health and safety.
On the twenty-first day of the month of Ramadan, a man was killed in Suq Saruja, and they arrested his killer. On Monday, the twenty-third of the month of Ramadan, a man was found hanged in the Palace of the Saraya in the Grooms' quarter where the furnace of Hammam al-Malika is. He remained hanging shortly before Asr, and his killer was not known. The Pasha ordered his burial, and he went in vain.
On the twenty-fifth, a slain man was found in the cemetery of Bab al-Saghir near the grave of Yazid, and his killer was not known. In this year, we fasted Ramadan thirty days, and Eid al-Fitr was Tuesday.
On Wednesday, the sixteenth of Shawwal, the Aleppo Hajj came. The next day, the seventeenth, the procession of the Noble Mahmal left accompanied by its Amir and Amir of Damascus Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha. On the nineteenth, the Syrian caravan followed it.
On the eve of Monday before midnight, Ahmad Basha bin al-Qaltaqji and his entourage, Abdullah bin Hamza and his group, Kamal Khalil, Anbar Basha, and Ahmad Basha Daqmaq approached, along with a group of Druze who were fugitives, and with them sixty Druze men from Ibn Talhuq's group. They descended in the Maydan quarter, burned the gate of Al-Qabbani's house, and entered his house with trills and shouting. They looted everything in it of goods and others, saw none of the men, and did not approach the harem. They looted two warehouses of wheat and barley. They looted the house of Al-Hajj Isma'il bin Zu'aytar, who was the Sheikh of Camel Drivers, and did not approach the harem; the owner of the house was in Hajj. They looted the house of Abd al-Fattah Agha Bash Shawish, because he was the greatest oppression upon them, and after their flight he used to harm their families. Then they arrested his son and said: If you do not inform us about your father we kill you, and if you guide us to him you have safety. Out of fear, he brought him out to them hiding in a latrine. They killed him and killed with him a man from the Saraya entourage who was passing by them while they were killing him.
When Musa Kikhiya, Mutasallim of Damascus, learned of their deed, he sent for the Governor, Mufti, and Judge, and ordered them to take the Sanjak with them, and called them Kharijites (rebels), and whoever loved Allah, His Messenger, and the Sultan should go out to fight them. The Mutasallim Musa Kikhiya went out with the Kapikulu, Dalatiyya, and Tafakjiya. When they approached Suq al-Suwayqa, they called out to them and sought them. They were staying in the Maydan coffeehouse. Then when they reached Bab al-Musalla, they attacked them from all sides of the Maydan. They killed a group of them and wounded many. They shot the Mutasallim's horse and the Mufti's horse, and returned disappointed.
The next day, Sheikh Ibrahim al-Jabawi, may Allah benefit us by him, went to them. They met him and kissed his hands. He said to them: O my children, what is your desire? They said: The Druze prisoners be released to us, our coming is for their sake. He said to them: Tomorrow I return the answer to you. So they stayed that day without fighting. The next day Sheikh Ibrahim came to them and said: O my children, be patient until the Pasha comes or we send to him until his answer comes.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
Al-Budayri said: A man from the Turks came on the morning of that day with a number of Dalatiyya. They were in Sidon, so His Excellency As'ad Pasha sent requesting them to serve under his Mutasallim in Damascus. These were the first to strike with the sword, loot, and rob in the movement of the Zarb in Damascus. Their leader was called Abdullah the Turk.
On Wednesday, a great massacre occurred, in which about fifty killed fell, from the group of the Mutasallim and Kapikulu. One of the Druze went out and killed two boys. The people of Damascus spent the night and morning in the most ominous state. Then the Mutasallim sent and brought fifty horsemen from Bani Sakhr, and sent to the villages and peasants, until he had a huge army. In those days, the firing of guns and cannons did not cease night and day. The Pasha's soldiers opened the shops of Bab al-Jabiya, looted, ate, drank, demolished the benches and made them barricades.
On Thursday, they went early for fighting, and marched towards Al-Suwayqa, with laborers and builders, and burned houses and palaces. After noon, they tightened on the Zarb, the wretches, besieged them, and fired cannons at them, so they turned their backs. They followed them and cut off four heads from them, including the head of Musa Jurbaji, who was counted among the Zarb. He was among those who fled, and was not killed until he charged at the Mutasallim's army four times, with bullets falling on him like rain, until a bullet hit him. He fell, so they cut off his head and brought it to the Saraya. As for Kor Uthman, he was fighting behind barricades, without a weapon but with stones, until a bullet hit him entering from the right of his head and exiting from the left. He fell, and his companions carried him and returned broken and disappointed.
The soldiers attacked Al-Maydan, and left no place in it but entered it. The Mutasallim permitted them to loot and rob from Al-Suwayqa to the end of Al-Maydan. So they looted and killed. No house or shop remained but they looted and demolished it. They robbed wealth, killed men, captured women, and exposed their women. This lasted until Asr time.
Then a group of Zarb came, with a division of Druze and a group of Maydan people. They repelled them from the rest of Al-Maydan. Then when this group that repelled them knew they had no power against those crowds, they fled escaping at night, with a group of Maydan people.
When day broke, the ruler called for safety (Aman), and that markets be opened and no one loots, and whoever loots or takes something, his soul and money will be taken. Then the Agha of Kapikulu went up to Al-Maydan, and people went out to see what happened in it.
The historian Ahmad al-Budayri said: I walked with those who walked, and found it a barren plain. The dead were thrown in it, doors broken, shops ruined, and walls demolished. In summary, its state was a state from which bodies shiver and children turn gray. The Almighty said: "And whatever strikes you of disaster - it is for what your hands have earned; but He pardons much." (Al-Shura: 30).
Friday morning came, and the people of Al-Qubaybat and remaining houses of Al-Maydan, Bab al-Musalla, and Al-Suwayqa were moving their belongings and what remained of them to inside the city, Al-Qanawat, and Bab al-Sarija. Tremors, fear, worry, and grief fell in Damascus. The elite and commoners feared, even shop owners began moving what they had and placing it inside houses. The houses looted in that incident were one thousand nine hundred houses. As for shops, they cannot be counted by number or calculation. The Kapikulu began taking people and bringing them to the ruler saying to him: This one was fighting with the Zarb, and this one with the Druze, and this and this. The Mutasallim would kill them without law or proof. Each of them intended to take revenge on his enemies.
As for the house of Al-Qabbani, an alert occurred from the Mutasallim that whoever took anything from it from the common people should bring it. So the commoners began bringing everything they took of wheat, goods, and dirhams, even bringing sealed money bags. The historian said: Such are fortunes. Matters tightened on the people of Damascus, and they began staying up night and day. People were in worry, grief, and high prices. Every time panic and shop closing occurred, until most houses that were outside the city moved to inside it and to the Citadel.
On Thursday, Sa'd al-Din Pasha, brother of As'ad Pasha al-Azm, entered with an army like a raging sea. He was informed of all that happened, so he got angry at the Mutasallim, and harbored distress for him.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
In this incident, the attracted Saint (Majdhub) Sheikh Ibrahim, nicknamed Al-Kiki, passed away. He was a blessed man, and his father was a righteous man from the Qubaybat district. In most of his times, he would beat his hands, lean backwards and forwards, and call out at the top of his voice: 'Walak Kiki Ya Ghawwas', and sometimes he would weep and say: 'Baddi Imra'ah Hatta...' (I want a woman so that...), and people would say to him: What do you have in a woman? He would say: A woman is a bread (Khubza). He had occurrences and miracles. Among his miracles transmitted about him and became famous is that one day he saw a man selling yogurt cans. He shouted at the yogurt seller and said 'Baddi ulbah' (I want a can), and began weeping and beating his hands. People gathered and brought out a can for him. The Sheikh said while weeping: I want only this one, and pointed to one of the yogurt cans. They brought it out for him. He took it in his hand and emptied it on the ground, and lo, a snake came down from it. He left it and went away. He has many other miracles.
The cause of his death was that a bullet hit his leg. He began weeping and calling: O my father, O Ghawwas, a wasp stung me. He died days later, may Allah have mercy on him.
On Tuesday, the sixth of Dhu al-Hijjah, Musa Kikhiya, Mutasallim of Damascus, sent two banners of Dalatiyya with some of their group. They brought him Isma'il Agha Ibn al-Shawish in chains. He was residing in some villages as Subashi. He raised him to the Citadel. Likewise, they brought him his brother Sulayman Agha Ibn al-Hamli and Ahmad Agha Ibn Asakir, and arrested them. It was mentioned to the Mutasallim that they were helping the Druze and Zarb.
On Saturday was the Day of Arafah (Waqfa) for Eid al-Adha in Damascus, that year. It was a year of many terrors and pains. Much smallpox occurred in it until it annihilated and killed many children. Glory be to the Everlasting after annihilation.

Year 1162
Then the year one thousand one hundred and sixty-two entered, and its first Muharram was Saturday. It is hoped from Allah, Blessed and Exalted, that it be a blessed year upon us and upon all our Muslim brothers. Now people are in distress and extra confinement from the abundance of high prices and hardships. But people rejoiced in good due to the abundant rains that fell at the beginning of this year. The litterateur of Damascus, Sheikh Abd al-Rahman, made a good chronogram and a good omen for this year, and included it within these two verses. He said:
A new year we hope from our Lord ... in it increase of good and boons.
Perhaps He enriches us with His vast bounty ... since He encompassed us I dated: 'Am Ghina'' (Year of Wealth).
On Monday, the second of Muharram of this year, our Sheikh, the Muhaddith of the Syrian lands, rather the seal of Muhaddithin, of whom Damascus was proud over the rest of the world, Sheikh Isma'il al-Ajluni, the teacher under the Dome of the Eagle in the Umayyad Mosque, passed away. No one remained of the people of Damascus, old or young, but attended his funeral. He was buried in the cemetery of Sheikh Arslan, may Allah be pleased with him. May Allah compensate Islam with good.
In those days, Ibrahim Agha, Agha of the Kapikulu, separated from his position for months, passed away. He was religious, humble, adhering to congregational prayer in the Umayyad Mosque, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him.
On the twenty-seventh of Muharram, the Jukhadar of Hajj approached, and three days later the writer of Hajj came. On the eve of Thursday, the Noble Hajj entered, the fifth day of Safar al-Khayr. On the eve of Friday, the gentle young man of lofty status and noble origin, descendant of the Sadiyya Masters and the Siddiqi branch, Sheikh Bakri bin Sheikh Mustafa bin Sa'd al-Din, passed away, because his father was from the house of Sa'd al-Din, and his mother from the house of Al-Bakri. May Allah have mercy on him and compensate him with Paradise, Amen.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
In the early part of the month of Safar, a house in the 'Uqayba neighborhood collapsed on a group, killing seven of them. A man and his wife survived; his name was Sa'id bin al-Shakush. On the tenth of Rabi' al-Awwal, severe painful cold occurred. Charcoal began to be sold on trays, carried on heads, every rotl for five masari, peddled in markets and neighborhoods. This was days before the entry of Husum (unlucky days/cold period), and continued until Husum entered.
On the seventeenth of Rabi' al-Awwal, Jukhadariyya arrived from Istanbul and entered upon the Amir al-Hajj and Governor of Damascus Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha al-Azm. He showed that glad tidings came to him from the High Presence, so he ordered fireworks called 'Shenk'. The Kapikulu and soldiers ran towards the Saraya, so the people of Damascus thought an incident occurred, and the city closed down. They informed the Pasha of that, so he said: Fire cannons and make another Shenk. They did, so people calmed down, and their shops opened.
In those days, some Turks from the Kapikulu got drunk and wounded three persons from the locals. Days later they died from their wounds, and no claim was raised for them.
High prices increased and calamity grew. Bread was a rotl for six masari for the poor quality, medium for eight masari, and good for twelve masari. An ounce of ghee for seven masari, an ounce of oil for two masriyyahs, and meat a rotl for thirty-six masari. Prostitutes roamed night and day. People were in great distress.
In the month of Rabi' al-Awwal, news reached Damascus that a flood occurred in Tripoli of Syria greater than the one that happened in Damascus mentioned before. That was because the river of Tripoli rose greatly and flooded its people until it drowned more than five hundred humans, besides animals, livestock, and wealth. We seek refuge in Allah from the wrath of the Compeller.
In those days, the aides of Zahir Umar, Sheikh of Tiberias, raided camels traveling from Damascus, looted their people and took their wealth. The reason for that was that in his land and territory were Arabs and Turkmens, and As'ad Pasha had ordered them to raid them. So they raided them, looted them, took their wealth and sheep, and killed a group of them. They came with their sheep, so the Pasha distributed them on the villages and butchers of Damascus. What was worth a piastre, he imposed forcibly for five piastres, and so on.
In this month, a rotl of bread went from eight masari to twelve masari, Ma'ruk to seventeen masari, a rotl of garlic to twenty-four masari, a ghirara of wheat to fifty-two piastres, a ghirara of corn to forty-eight, eggs two for a masriyyah, a rotl of rice to fifteen masari, and a rotl of charcoal to six masari. Everything exceeded its limit, and judgment is for Allah regarding His servant.
In the month of Rabi' al-Thani, As'ad Pasha killed three individuals from the Matawila and killed Al-Bathish from the group of Zarb wretches fleeing during the days of the incident.
On Monday, the fourth of Jumada al-Thani of this year, the Judge of Damascus Sayyid Muhammad Effendi Bashmaqji Zade entered.
The historian Al-Budayri said: It reached me that Hamid Effendi Ibn al-Imadi, Mufti of Damascus, had hoarded wheat like the grandees and notables who do not fear the Merciful, the Compassionate. The measurers came to him and said: We sell wheat, every ghirara for fifty piastres. He said to them: Wait, perhaps the price will increase. If the Mufti of Muslims has no compassion for Allah's creation, do not blame others.
In these days, they held a council, and informed As'ad Pasha of the abundance of evils and gathering of prostitute women in alleys and markets, and that they sleep on shops and in bakeries and coffeehouses. He said: Let us make a way for them either by deporting them or placing them in a place they do not exceed, or we consider their matter. He said: I will do nothing of these conditions, nor let them pray against me night and day. Then the council dispersed, and no benefit resulted from their meeting.
In those days, high prices increased in the lands of Sham. It reached us that a rotl of bread in Tripoli was ten masari, in Gaza and Ramla twenty-five masari, and in Damascus it was not stable on a price. High prices, calamity, and oppression increased.
The historian Al-Budayri said: In these days, As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus, bought many properties of houses, orchards, mills, and other things. This was before building his house and Qaysariyya.
On the eighth of Jumada al-Thani of this year, new barley came down. They sold barley bread a rotl for four masari, and white for six. Then the next day the crier went out that wheat bread be sold for four masari and white for six masari. No result occurred for the poor; every day a new price, and Allah does what He wills.
On Thursday, the twelfth of Jumada al-Ula, the virtuous scholar Sheikh Abd al-Wahhab al-Dalati passed away, may Allah have mercy on him.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On Wednesday, the eleventh of Jumada al-Thani, new wheat came down. A ghirara of wheat was sold for forty-five piastres, while before its arrival it was fifty-two. The common people shouted and sought help, and looted some bakeries. Then they began calling in the markets a rotl of bread for three masari and four masari. So all people of Damascus sold at that price. The people of the city rejoiced greatly, so the city was decorated.
His Excellency Governor As'ad Pasha was in his father's garden in Masjid al-Aqsab having a picnic with the notables of Damascus. When this news reached him, he became extremely angry, and ordered Al-Hajj Mahmoud Tafakji Bashi to take his immoral aides and go around the city and markets, and warn the bakers not to sell a rotl of bread except for six masari and the black for four, and whoever disobeys will get a beating. Beware, then beware. So they returned to the first method, bread blackened and changed, and Allah is Greatest and Most Jealous.
On the sixteenth of Jumada al-Ula, a ghirara of wheat became twenty-six piastres, so a rotl of bread was sold for three masari, and distress began to disappear by the permission of Allah Almighty.
In those days, news reached Damascus that Abdullah Agha bin Hamza and Kamal Khalil, who were among the heads of the Zarbawat defeated from Damascus, were captured by Zahir Umar, ruler of Tiberias Fortress. He cut off their heads and sent them to Sidon, and the governor of Sidon sent them to the State, and sent asking for a Noble Decree that As'ad Pasha, ruler of Damascus, should not pass through the land of Tiberias in his travel on the Dawra.
On Monday, the first of Rajab the Unique of this year, As'ad Pasha, ruler of Damascus, called out that whoever drank coffee would be hanged and crucified. Then he ordered its removal, so it was removed from all coffeehouses and markets of Damascus. The historian Al-Budayri said: Drinking it in Damascus had become one of the greatest calamities; men, women, and even girls drank it. May Allah reward him with good.
On the third of Rajab, the bakers and market people called out that a rotl of bread is four masari and the special five masari, and that mixed with corn or barley two masari. Out of the abundance of joy of the people of Damascus, especially the poor, they began weeping and wailing with joy, as Allah relieved them. Most markets of Damascus were decorated. On that day, a ghirara of good wheat and barley was sold for eight piastres. Allah relieved His servants by His favor and generosity.
On Friday, the second of blessed Sha'ban, Khalil Agha and Ahmad Agha, sons of Ibn al-Darzi, entered and met the Mutasallim of Damascus. He received them with the best reception. They had a Boyuruldu (decree) from As'ad Pasha, as they met him through the mediation of Sheikh Ibrahim al-Sa'di al-Jabawi, may Allah benefit us by him and his ancestors. They were fugitives with the Arabs. He gave them safety (Aman), when it appeared they had no guilt in those deeds.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
The crescent of Ramadan appeared this year. Two days before Ramadan, the Judge of Damascus Sayyid Muhammad Effendi Bashmaqji Zade went out to Salihiyya with his harem. Then he returned at Asr time from Salihiyya with his harem, drawing a weapon with a pistol in his hand, one foot with a slipper (babuj) and the second barefoot without a slipper. He had wounded a person from his group. He remained in this state until he reached the court. Then it appeared he was drunk...
The historian said: I investigated the reason for the Judge descending in this manner, and the matter appeared contrary to what we mentioned of him being drunk. Rather, it was from a sharpness of temper that occurred from him. The reason for that is he had a concubine, and he was infatuated with her, so much that he divorced his wife for her sake. His wife wanted to disturb his life. One day some guests came for his concubine whom he loved. She wanted to put food, chicken, and other things before the guests from what the Judge prepared for lunch in Salihiyya. The Judge's wife prevented her, and she was not generous. When the Judge came, his concubine informed him of that, and that she did not put food or anything before my guests, then she began to weep. The Judge loved her extraordinarily. So he rose against his wife and divorced her, as it was said that was the reason for her divorce. He rose against his servants and drew a weapon on them, ordered the harem to descend, and demanded his mount, but they were slow. Then he found a single slipper so he went down with it to the bridge, then rode and went down to the court in that state. His enemies claimed he was drunk while the matter was otherwise.
Then this action did not suffice his divorced wife, until she complained against him to the Sublime State. The order came with a decree of his dismissal and exile to the island of Cyprus and seizing all his wealth for his wife. They sold all his belongings, and took all the money he had, amounting to eight purses, and gave them to his divorced wife. This was by order of the State. Then most people regretted him, other than those with agendas, due to what the mentioned Judge was upon of integrity, contentment, humility, and great generosity, such that in the month of Ramadan he would eat a qintar of ghee and of rice likewise, and of meat likewise, so that at least there would be about thirty people at his place in Ramadan besides the poor. Since he did not take bribes nor incline in a lawsuit, the people of Damascus turned against him with his wife, until they heard of his dismissal as is their custom of old.
On Sunday, mid-Shawwal, the Treasury of Egypt came to Damascus. On Monday, the sixteenth of Shawwal, the Noble Mahmal left with its Amir Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha bin Isma'il Pasha al-Azm. This was the seventh Hajj for the mentioned His Excellency As'ad Pasha. His father Isma'il Pasha had performed Hajj six times. This Hajj in this year is the seventh for As'ad Pasha.
The day after the Mahmal's departure, the Mutasallim hanged two of the wretched thieves. They had many incidents. It was finally proven that they broke into a house at night and stole all expensive items in it. The name of one of them was Sheikh of the Takiyya.
Four days after the Syrian Hajj left, Sayyid Yunus, partner of As'ad Pasha, left with a huge caravan accompanied by a large group, and they caught up with the Pasha and Hajj at Muzayrib.
In this year, As'ad Pasha renewed the upper rooms in his father Isma'il Pasha's Madrasa in Suq al-Khayyatin, made a mosque and Khutba in its southern part, and arranged parts of Quran, soup, oil, and other things. May Allah reward him with good.
On the ninth of Dhu al-Qi'dah, the Judge mentioned before traveled to Sidon, intending Cyprus with the intention of exile to it. Some notables went out to bid him farewell.
On the fifteenth of Dhu al-Qi'dah, they publicly shamed three persons and circulated them in the whole city, faces blackened, riding donkeys backwards. We asked the reason, and it was said they mint Ramliyyah flus (coins), which is fraud. One was Kurdish and the second Dagestani.
On that day, the ruler ordered to expel the daughters of passion, the sluts, from the city to outside the city, and showed he wanted to exile them to other lands. He warned the neighborhood Sheikhs that whoever a suspicious person is found in his neighborhood has only himself to blame. Then a crier called out that women should not lower veils over their faces, except the Pasha's harem and Musa Kikhiya's women. Then the ruler's aides began inspecting and were strict. Some distress was relieved. Then this strictness did not last but a few days, when we saw the mentioned girls walking as their habit in alleys and markets and more. They returned to the city, and the ruler arranged on them ten piastres on each one every month and appointed a Subashi over them; rather, he cut from people and robbed. Allah is the Helper.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On Tuesday, Sa'd al-Din Pasha, brother of As'ad Pasha bin al-Azm, entered Damascus with a great procession, because he is the Sardar of the Jarda and its Amir, and he had marched with it in the past year.

Year 1163
Then the year one thousand one hundred and sixty-three entered, and its first Muharram was Thursday. The cold is great and high prices remaining, did not cease. Bread remained at five masari, a rotl of rice at twelve masari, a rotl of meat at twenty-four masari, a rotl of charcoal at three masari, a rotl of dibs at eight masari, and an ounce of ghee at five masari. The ice that occurred this year, we have not heard its like. We ask Allah Almighty for kindness.
In the middle of Muharram of this year, the working scholar Sheikh Muhammad al-Dayri passed away. He used to teach in the Umayyad Mosque, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him. Two days after him, the ascetic scholar Sheikh Mulla Abbas al-Kurdi, successor of his Sheikh Mulla Ilyas al-Kurdi, passed away in his place in Al-Addas Mosque, may Allah have mercy on him, and was buried at the foot of Mount Qasioun.
On the twenty-eighth of Muharram, Sheikh Isa, Imam of the first prayer in the Umayyad Mosque in the niche of the Shafi'i Masters, passed away. He, may Allah have mercy on him, was a righteous man, good in recitation, good voice, always wearing white clothes, and his turban of white wool. His funeral was attended by many, only a few lagged behind. He was buried in the Baramika cemetery south of Al-Marja, may Allah have mercy on him.
On that day, the sun eclipsed, and remained eclipsed for about three hours. People prayed the eclipse prayer in the Umayyad Mosque.
The entry of the Noble Hajj that year was on Wednesday, the fifth of Safar. The next day, Thursday, the Amir al-Hajj As'ad Pasha entered with the procession of the Noble Mahmal. This is the seventh year of his consecutive pilgrimages. Pilgrims mentioned that this year is the most blessed, best, and cheapest of years going and returning. His Excellency Sa'd al-Din Pasha entered with his brother As'ad Pasha, both in utmost health.
On the twenty-fifth of Muharram, the Mutasallim of Damascus Musa Kikhiya hanged five persons of the wretched Druze. In those days, the Judge of Mecca died and was buried in Bab al-Saghir.
