On Sunday, the twenty-third of Safar, the ascetic Saint Sheikh Muhammad bin Abd al-Hadi al-Umari passed away. They prayed over him in the Umayyad, and he was buried in Marj al-Dahdah. His funeral was crowded with men and women, may Allah have mercy on him.
On the twenty-fifth of Safar, the Pasha hanged three men. The people of Douma brought them to Governor As'ad Pasha, informing him they found with them a saddlebag containing goods belonging to the Sultan's Kaftaji. He ordered their crucifixion.
On Saturday, the last of Safar, Sa'd al-Din Pasha traveled to the place of his assignment which is in Tripoli. In those days, Sheikh Mustafa al-Kurdi, who was residing in the Madrasa of Sulayman Pasha bin al-Azm, passed away. He was a religious jurist. He was buried at the foot of Qasioun, may Allah have mercy on him. In these days also, Najib Effendi al-Safarjalani passed away. He was among the leaders of Damascus notables. He had a great funeral and was buried in the cemetery of Bab al-Saghir.
Also passed away in those days, in early Rabi' al-Awwal of this year, the righteous scholar Sheikh Mustafa bin Sheikh Shu'ayb from the neighborhood of Bab al-Sarija. He had a great funeral with flags, and all Sheikhs of Tariqas went out in his funeral. He was buried in Bab al-Saghir, may Allah have mercy on him.
In those days also passed away the ascetic Saint, whom divine attraction overcame, Sayyid Mustafa bin Sheikh Murad. The state and acceptance in Damascus and Istanbul belonged to his nephew Sayyid Ali Effendi. All notables went out in his funeral and he was buried in Bab al-Saghir, may Allah have mercy on him.
On the eve of Monday, the perfect Saint of apparent miracles and dazzling states, who cast off restraint and night and day were equal to him, drank from the wine of the Compeller's drink, and was given the degree of acceptance among great and small, Sheikh Muhammad Jabri, passed away. He used to sometimes be absent, sometimes present, and sometimes intoxicated. He had a group and disciples, and was in the rank of Sheikh Ahmad al-Nahlawi, whom he used to visit during his life. When Al-Nahlawi died, a group of the Sheikh's poor (Fuqara) stuck to him, going around with him and sleeping where he slept. His death was in Bab al-Sarija, and he had a great funeral.
In the middle of Sa'd al-Dhabih, snow came for two days and two nights without interruption and was not followed by rain. It remained on roofs and in alleys for more than twenty days, until a rotl of charcoal became half a piastre and a third, a rotl of bread from four masari to eight, an ounce of ghee five masari, and a rotl of meat thirty masari. In summary, everything is expensive, and creation is in trouble of mind.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
In those days, a Kapikulu killed a Sharif man after Isha. The mother of the killed complained to Vizier As'ad Pasha and stuck to him. He ordered bringing him, so they caught him after he fled. The Vizier ordered strangling him, so he was strangled in the Citadel.
In those days, the literary poet and intelligent virtuous man, whom no poet in his time wove on his loom, Sheikh Abd al-Rahman al-Bahlul passed away, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him. He was buried in Bab al-Saghir opposite the houses of Al-Nahhana from the side of Al-Shaghour. This Al-Bahlul, possessor of acceptance, is the author of the poem with which he praised the Master Sheikh Abd al-Ghani al-Nabulsi containing more than a hundred dates (chronograms); in every hemistich there is a date. When he presented the poem to his praised master, and the Sheikh saw it was unique in its kind with this astonishing wondrous format, he said to him: We have sought Allah's guidance regarding you, O Sheikh Abd al-Rahman, and made you the Sheikh of Literature in Damascus.
On Monday, the fifteenth of Rabi' al-Awwal, the roof of the narrow market behind the Umayyad Mosque which contains the coffeehouse fell. Its fall was after the Hanafi prayer. A group was under it; four persons died and a group was crushed.
The historian Al-Budayri said: On Thursday, the eighteenth of Rabi' al-Awwal, we went out for a picnic to the Sharaf area overlooking Al-Marja with some of our loved ones. The time was at the beginning of blossoming. We sat overlooking Al-Marja and the Salimiyya Takiyya. Behold, women more than men were sitting on the edge of the river, eating, drinking, coffee, and tobacco, just as men do. This is something we never heard its like occurred until we witnessed it. There is no power or strength except with Allah.
The historian said: Then we continued in joy and relaxation, until I recited these Mawaliya saying:
A day passed for us, its like never preceded, O uncle ... In the meadow of Sham you don't see an empty place.
What a Thursday passed, no villains encountered it ... On the eighteenth of Rabi' al-Akhir the cold went.
O people of literature date it: Distress has gone from you.
On that day, an architect fell from the roof of Suq al-Khayyatin and died instantly.
The next day, Friday, the nineteenth of Rabi' al-Akhir, Sheikh Muhammad bin Jaqayjaqa passed in Al-Amara carrying cauliflower in his hand, when he fell to the ground lifeless. He was carried to his house dead, may Allah have mercy on him.
In those days, As'ad Pasha took the house of Mu'awiyah, may Allah be pleased with him, and took what was around it of Khans, houses, and shops, demolished them, and began building his house, the famous Saraya which is south of the Umayyad Mosque. He strove and exerted effort in its building night and day. He cut for it from a total of timber a thousand timbers, besides what the notables of the city and grandees sent him of timber and other things. He ordered the baths of the city not to sell Qasarmal (cinder) to anyone, but send it to the building of the Saraya. Most teachers (masters) of the city and its carpenters worked on it, as well as painters. Indeed, rarely is a master craftsman or carpenter or painter found but all are working on it. He brought tiles for it from most houses of the city; wherever tiles or marble and other things like columns and basins were found, he sent and uprooted them for a small price.
Near the Baramika cemetery was a palace called Al-Zahrabiyya. It was said to be built by King Al-Zahir. It is on the back of Baniyas overlooking Al-Marja. It was a great promenade place, most of it demolished. Near it is a tomb with a stone dome, the top of the dome uprooted. It has a depression; it was said there was an ancient treasure in its top so it was taken.
The historian said: It reached me about the reason for taking it that written on the door of the dome wall was these Mawaliya:
Manage your time and your companion then manage her ... And avoid people high and low.
If they ask you about people's faults cover them ... The mind in the head is its judge and governor.
Everyone who read it imagined something, until the owner of the share came at night, climbed to the top of the dome, dug it and took what was in it. It remained headless until our time, until they informed His Excellency Vizier As'ad Pasha al-Azm, owner of the building, about this dome and the tomb beside it, and that riffraff and wretches gather there night and day for immorality and corruption and other things. So he ordered demolishing it immediately and transporting its stones to his house.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
In those days, it reached His Excellency Vizier As'ad Pasha that in the house of Ibn Kaywan there was an old mill, called the Monks' Mill, which had been demolished and only the traces of its bottom remained, and that it was installed on Baniyas. Immediately His Excellency the Pasha ordered cutting off the Baniyas river and extracting all columns and stones in it and transporting them to the house. Laborers, stonemasons, and gardeners worked, and continued uprooting stones and transporting them to the Pasha's house for twelve days, while the river was cut off from its owners.
On Thursday, the twenty-sixth of Rabi' al-Thani of this year, Hasan Effendi al-Safarjalani held a banquet for His Excellency As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus, in Salihiyya in the hall of Ibn Qarnaq. It was a great hospitality, said to cost about eleven hundred piastres. His Excellency the Pasha looked at towering cypress trees in his house, and requested their owner Ali Agha bin Qarnaq to cut them for the building of his house. As'ad Pasha, owner of the building, offered him some money, but he refused to take anything of their price, and cut for him three cypresses having no equal in Damascus or elsewhere. He transported from the village of Bosra stones and marble columns, a lot of them. He took from the Madrasa of King Al-Nasir in Salihiyya thick columns brought loaded on carts pulled by oxen. He demolished the Zanuziyya market above the Amara district, which was all vaulted arches, ordered dismantling it and transporting it to his referenced house. He also transported to it columns from Yilbugha Mosque. Whatever he heard of exquisite tiles, columns, or stones from any place, he would bring them by purchase or otherwise.
The historian Ahmad al-Budayri, may Allah forgive him, said: In those days, Ibn Khattab al-Dalati was killed in Suq al-Bazuriyya at the time of Isha Adhan. A weapon blow came to his head, taking half his neck with his head, so he fell dead as if he never was. This while the Vizier of Damascus is busy building his house, paying no attention to his subjects and supporters, saying: Bring me marble and alabaster stones and cypress, and excel in building, engraving, and adorning with gold and silver. He brought marble columns on carts and oxen from Bosra, destroyed the market of Masjid al-Aqsab, brought all stones and wood in it. Whenever he heard of a piece or masterpiece of marble or Qishani or others, he sent and brought it whether its owner accepted or refused.
If a poor man wanted to build or repair, he found no architect, carpenter, wood, nail, soil, cinder, or stones. This with high prices and descent of distress. His Excellency the Pasha took an ample amount of Qanawat water, so it did not reach the Saraya until paths and waters of most mosques and baths were cut off, and it remained cut off for a while even from most houses.
In those days, Ali Effendi al-Muradi held a hospitality for His Excellency As'ad Pasha in the village of Babbila on the road to the Lady's Tomb (Qabr al-Sitt). It was a crowded hospitality for lunch and dinner.
In those days also, His Excellency Vizier As'ad Pasha al-Azm ordered the administrator of the Umayyad Mosque, Sheikh Ibrahim al-Jabawi al-Sa'di, to fix the conditions of the mentioned Mosque and inspect its interests. Immediately they started restoring the western minaret, removed idle stones in it, removed old mats and carpets in it, and furnished it with new furnishing by the determination of His Excellency the Pasha.
On Monday, the sixth of Jumada al-Ula, Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha went out and had a picnic in the land of Ghouta, accompanied by the grandees and notables of Damascus.
On Friday, the tenth day of Jumada al-Ula, while people were at Friday prayer, a man threw himself from the Citadel of Damascus towards the Manakhiliyya coffeehouse. His hands and legs were broken. The reason for his imprisonment was that he was accused of deflowering a girl.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
In those days in the Roman month of Adhar (March), a severe storm wind blew the like of which was not heard. The regions of Damascus shook from it, until people thought the Resurrection had risen. It was followed by severe cold and continuous rain until the end of the night.
In those days, a man from the Turks came to Damascus, with a copper plate which he places on a stick and spins it on it, throws it up the height of two men, catches it on the stick while spinning, and transfers it from finger to finger while spinning, collecting money from spectators. Then the boys of Damascus began doing like his deed. He was amazed at that and mentioned he toured many countries in the world and no one could do like his deed. Then he traveled and was not seen afterwards.
Stranger than that, a man also from the sons of Turks came before the one we mentioned. He claps with his fingers, hitting one on the other, stomps his foot on the ground firmly, and sings in Turkish and Arabic. People gather around him and give him money. Small boys of Damascus began doing like his deed and better. He mentioned he toured many cities in the world and no one learned this craft except boys of Damascus, and was astonished by their intelligence.
In Jumada al-Akhira, a man was killed in the 'Uqayba district. We asked the reason, and it was said he was a man working in a bakery. He went to his bakery at the end of the night, locked his house door, and left his wife sleeping. When he reached his bakery and settled for a while, a warner came to him and informed him he saw men entering his house. He came running immediately, found the latch open, felt the door and found it bolted. He shouted at his wife and she answered him. He said to her: Who is with you? She shouted: Oh my honor! Who would be with me? He said to her: Open the door. She made excuses of inability to open the door. He shouted loudly, and behold the door opened and men came out of it. One of them hit him with a pistol in his chest killing him instantly. When day broke, they informed His Excellency Vizier of Damascus As'ad Pasha. He brought the woman before him and asked her, she denied, so he ordered her imprisonment. She was imprisoned and her husband's blood went in vain.
In those days also, a woman who killed her husband was brought to His Excellency Vizier As'ad Pasha. He asked her the reason. She said to him: He married [another] over me. When it was my night, he slept and left me, so I got up and cut off his penis, and said: Neither for me nor for her. So he died from that. His Excellency the Vizier laughed and did nothing to her except ordering her imprisonment.
On the twenty-first day of Jumada al-Thani of this year, the Governor of Damascus went to the Dawra, and his Mutasallim was Musa Agha Kikhiya. The second day of the Pasha's departure, his mentioned Mutasallim hanged two, said to be Matawila who were highwaymen. Then he announced that no one after Isha prayer should go out, neither with light nor without light. This is something that never preceded. Then he himself began patrolling at night. He was among the tyrants.
In this year, the first of Rajab was proven Saturday, the night of mid-Sha'ban was the eve of Monday, and the first of Ramadan was Tuesday.
On the sixteenth of Ramadan, the Surra Emini procession entered; the Treasury of Egypt also entered Damascus. On the twenty-first of it, the Baltajiyya entered.
On the eve of the twenty-fourth after Tarawih prayer, a Kurd called Kara Mustafa was killed in Al-Hadra, and his adversary was not known. They accused a Baghdadi man of it. The Kurds armed themselves and descended until they reached Al-Darwishiyya and Bab al-Jabiya hoping to encounter one of the Baghdadis to kill him, but found none. Crowds were in Al-Darwishiyya in rows and thousands. With the Kurds' attack, they scattered and fled, and fear and terror entered people's hearts. To Allah is the destination.
After three days, the Pasha arrived from the Dawra, his entry being with Maghrib Adhan.
At the end of Ramadan, the day of Waqfa (eve of Eid), the Kurds killed two Baghdadis to take revenge for the killed Kurd mentioned before. The Baghdadis and Mosulis armed themselves, helped by Tafakjiya and Kapikulu, and sought the Kurds' Khan. The Kurds fired a volley of bullets at them, killing a group and wounding [others]. They returned on the Kurds, looted some of their coffeehouses, and wanted to make a jumhuriyya (riot/rebellion) and raise sedition in the city. His Excellency the Vizier, may Allah preserve him, forbade them from that, and matters remained folded.
Eid al-Fitr was Wednesday, and we fasted Ramadan completely, after we used to fast it incomplete for years. After days, the Treasury of Egypt departed for Istanbul. On the seventeenth of Shawwal, the Amir al-Hajj departed with the Noble Mahmal and the lofty procession, Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha al-Azm. This year is the eighth of his consecutive pilgrimages. The next day the Aleppo Hajj came. On the twenty-first of Shawwal, the Syrian and Aleppo Hajj departed from Damascus. After five days, Hajj from the Persians came, and followed the Hajj to Muzayrib from the direction of Al-Lajat. The Hajj departed from Muzayrib on the twenty-seventh of Shawwal.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
After the Pasha's departure, the Mutasallim called out regarding Ramliyyah flus, every twenty-one fals for a masriyyah. He released the Baghdadi accused of killing Kara Mustafa the Kurd; they had raised him to the Citadel. Days after his release, he got drunk, rioted, and beat two donkey drivers killing them. The city was disturbed. The Mutasallim sent in search of him, but he fled and no trace appeared for him, nor did they find news of him. They arrested a Mamluk of his and strangled him.
Three days before His Excellency As'ad Pasha left for the Noble Hajj, the construction of the Pasha's house, which is for the harem, was completed. It was furnished with the best furnishings, and he moved his harem to it.
In those days, a great battle occurred between the Druze and Matawila. With the Matawila were also the sons of Zahir Umar, ruler of Tiberias. Killing occurred on both sides. They counted the Druze dead, and they were about nine hundred killed. It is a big sedition.
On Saturday, the fifth of Dhu al-Qi'dah, cannons were fired. We asked about the news, it was said a decree came from the Sultanate confirming As'ad Pasha al-Azm as Governor of Damascus.
The historian Al-Budayri said: On the eve of Wednesday, twenty past the month of Dhu al-Qi'dah of this year, Sheikh Isma'il, son of our Sheikh and teacher Sheikh Abd al-Ghani al-Nabulsi, passed away. He died leaving thirty children from his sons and grandsons. He lived seventy-seven years, because his birth was year one thousand eighty-five, and his father the Master's birth was year one thousand fifty, and his death year one thousand one hundred and forty-three, so the Master his father's age would be ninety-three years. His death was in Salihiyya, and he was buried in their house in Al-Anbariyya south of the Umayyad Mosque. His bier was carried to Salihiyya, and he was buried in his father's house next to his son Sheikh Tahir. May Allah Almighty have mercy on them and benefit us with their blessings all.

Year 1164
Then the year one thousand one hundred and sixty-four entered. The start of Muharram was Tuesday. May Allah make it a year of good and blessing upon us and the Muslims.
On the twenty-sixth of Muharram, the Jukhadar of the Noble Hajj came, and announced regarding Hajj all good of abundance of cheapness, water, and other things, praise be to Allah. However, high prices did not leave Damascus. This year entered with a rotl of bread at five and six masari, a rotl of rice ten masari, a rotl of meat twenty-eight masari, a rotl of dibs nine masari, an ounce of ghee six masari, currency is adulterated, flus are unminted, women unrestrained, men wandering, limits lost, notables busy, and men's chivalry tied, to the end of what the historian said.
In those days, they brought four heads of Arab highwaymen, brought by Isa Basha al-Habash, one of the fleeing Zarbawat, so he was pardoned for that.
On the twenty-ninth of Muharram, the Hajj writer came, and mentioned that this year is the most comfortable and best of years in the days of Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus, may Allah preserve him. Except that a great torrent came to them in Asfan, stalling them for days, then the Pasha ordered them to march earnestly until he left two out of ten, thus some pilgrims told me.
The Hajj entered on Wednesday, the second of Safar. The next day, Thursday, the Noble Mahmal entered, and As'ad Pasha and his brother Sa'd al-Din Pasha, Sardar of the Jarda, with the great procession.
On the eighth of Safar, the Judge of Damascus Abdullah Effendi Sa'id Zade entered at night, having majesty and awe, and did not speak with gossip.
It reached us that Uthman Pasha the Collector, Governor of Jeddah, died and was buried there.
In those days of this year, the position of Aleppo came to Sa'd al-Din Pasha, brother of As'ad Pasha. He moved from Tripoli with his family and went from Damascus to Aleppo. They rumored that his predecessor, the ruler of Aleppo, was unjust and tyrannical, destroyed many villages, built many buildings taking most expenses from the people of Aleppo, and built a mosque there that dazzles the eyes.
After Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha arrived from the Noble Hajj, we found his house construction completed. When he entered it, he increased in joy, delight, and happiness. He slaughtered sacrifices and gave gifts, and stayed in it with pleasure of life. The arrival of his confirmation in Damascus reached him, so he increased in thanks to the Lord of Creation.
However, the people of Damascus are in distress from high prices, miserliness of merchants, corruption of the free, weakness of the small, and lack of crowding of the great. Judgment is for Allah, the One, the Subduer. For a rotl of Damascene meat became a piastre, a rotl of ghee a piastre and a half, a rotl of buffalo meat twenty-four masari, fish likewise, a rotl of camel meat eighteen masari, an ounce of rice a masriyyah, honey an ounce for a shahiyya. A rotl of bread six masari, and people are in the worst conditions.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
In those days, a house in Bab al-Sarija collapsed on a woman and a small boy. In those days also, a Kurd and his wife were killed in the Suq Saruja district. The reason for that was he was a pilgrim, and when he came he found her changed in her conditions. Then it turned out she misbehaved in his absence. He was possessing strength (?) and beauty, so he slaughtered her and did not care about anyone.
In those days also, a man killed his daughter in the Suq Saruja district. She was four years old. Her matter reached His Excellency As'ad Pasha, that this girl's mother was divorced and her maternal aunt, her father's wife, did not love her, so she insinuated some words against her to her father. Her father had a great deal of stupidity and madness, so he beat her painfully with a stick, then tied her to a tree in his house. She remained tied all night until morning. He came to untie her and found her dead. It was a night of severe cold. As'ad Pasha summoned him and ordered him to be beaten severely. He was beaten then put in irons after taking much money from him.
On Wednesday, the eighth of Safar al-Khayr of this year, Sheikh Muhammad Abu Qamis al-Kurdi, Sheikh of the Muradiyya Madrasa, passed away. He was named Abu Qamis (Father of a Shirt) because if he wore a shirt he would not take it off until it tore. This is the utmost asceticism. He was fasting and praying night prayers. Notables and grandees went out in his funeral due to their belief in his righteousness. He was buried in the Marj al-Dahdah cemetery. When his room was opened, they found with him twenty new linen thobes, fifteen half-pieces, seven qintars of firewood, ten rotls of rice, a pot of ghee, a pot of honey, and other provisions. They found a pot with quarter riyals and similar masari, and in it gold, goods, needs, and two sacks full of shirts. They found about a hundred books they valued at a great price. Look at the asceticism of such a one; the good has gone with the bad.
On Friday, the tenth of Safar, Sheikh Ibrahim, Imam of Al-Qashmasiyya, passed away. He was a righteous jurist, buried in Bab al-Saghir cemetery, may Allah have mercy on him.
On Friday, the twenty-second of Rabi' al-Awwal, the skilled scholar Sheikh Ahmad al-Harasti, Secretary of Fatwa in the Imadi house, passed away, may Allah have mercy on him.
In those days, a man sold a jar of oil to another man, received its price after weighing it; then carried it to the man's house and said: Keep this jar with you, in an hour I will come to you and empty it for you. He said: No harm, rather I will empty it and whenever you come you find the jar. Then the oil owner went. An hour later the buyer emptied it, and found in it four ounces of oil and the rest clear water. He sought the man but did not find him.
On Saturday, the last of Rabi' al-Awwal, a Kapikulu killed a Sharif man in Ma'dhanat al-Shahm. He stabbed him with a dagger in his chest which came out of his back, and left the dagger stuck in him, until a judge viewing him took it out. Then they arrested the killer. The Ashraf rose. The killing was proven against him, so they imprisoned him in the Citadel, and that night they strangled him.
On Wednesday, the first of Jumada al-Ula, Sheikh Muhammad bin Sheikh Shu'ayb, famous as Sheikh Jina, residing in Bab al-Sarija district, passed away. He, may Allah have mercy on him, was smiling, gentle, of utmost righteousness. He was buried in Bab al-Saghir, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him.
On the eighth of Jumada al-Ula, a wretched man from Salihiyya known as Al-Fustuqi was assassinated. He was, as said, a dark calamity and a great disaster, brave repelling a hundred braves with a stick, a thief whose like was not heard among thieves famous for tricks. Among his tricks and cleverness which no equal was heard of, is that when he put his hand on the top of a wall, as soon as his nail caught it, he was on top of it, and the amazing thing is that his back is to the wall. If put in any place and the door closed on him and locked, he came out of it whatever it was. All this and he did not exceed twenty years of age. Then he aggressed against the people of Salihiyya especially and others, and his matter exhausted them. They set a reward for a person to kill him. So he assassinated him after befriending him, killed him, and he went as if he never was.
On Tuesday, news came to Damascus that on the eve of Monday, the governor of Baalbek, Emir Hasan, was killed. He was leaving the mosque, and three persons assassinated him, shot him with three guns and fled escaping. He was carried to his house. The second day he died. It was said his killers were his brothers, since he has seven brothers, and Allah knows best.
In those days, the Governor of Damascus As'ad Pasha imposed on Za'ims, notables, and merchants to bring him wheat from the city of Hama, and its wage be from them. Some of them went and brought much wheat. A ghirara was sold for thirty-one piastres. We did not benefit except its existence, as for high prices, it remains in all items as we presented its pricing.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On the eve of Saturday, Musa Kikhiya of As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus, passed away and was buried in Bab al-Saghir near the hill of Al-Shaghour. He had a great funeral. He, may Allah have mercy on him, was humble, sought knowledge in his early days, had compassion and kindness, and loved asking and reconciling disputants, until Damascus and its surroundings, even Bedouins, became obedient to him. He left three children: one became Governor of Jerusalem, the second Governor of Gaza, and the third small from his Damascene wife. He remained in the Kikhiya position from the rule of Sulayman Pasha to the seventh year of the rule of his nephew As'ad Pasha.
On Monday, the twenty-second of Jumada al-Thani, two Turkmen shepherds were killed in the land of Ghouta in Al-Mahfara. One of them survived, and was asked who did that to them. He informed that some Maghrebis thought they had money. So after they inflicted that upon them, they found with one a quarter riyal, and the second a few flus. So they returned losing this world and the Hereafter.
In those days, As'ad Pasha enlarged his new house, the like of which was not made, nor done, nor found in existence. While carpenters were raising scaffolds to raise the ceiling, eight carpenters fell and were crushed. Praise be to Allah, none of them was killed. His Excellency the Pasha ordered them sent to their homes, and gave each one half a gold coin.
In that year, As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus, bought from Salihiyya, land of Al-Inaba, and elsewhere, lands and orchards. He also bought Suq al-Daqq and shops around it, intending to make them a Qaysariyya having no equal in the Qaysariyyas of Damascus.
On Friday, the remnant of the Righteous Salaf, the belief of the people of Damascus absolutely, Sheikh Abd al-Latif bin Abd al-Hadi passed away. His lineage was read when prayer was established for him in the Maqsura of the Umayyad Mosque, and thirty grandfathers were found between him and our master Umar bin Al-Khattab. He had a great funeral and was buried in the cemetery of Marj al-Dahdah, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him.
On Monday, the last of Jumada al-Thani, the Yetmiş Iki (Seventy-Two) regiment of Kapikulu entered. Everyone with a wrapped turban went out to meet them, with two hundred Tafakjis and a group of Dalatiyya, all by order of the Pasha. It entered with an Arada, i.e., a procession, not [even like] the Noble Hajj procession. People went out to watch, men, women, old and young. They decorated the Amara neighborhood for them with lamps and torches. They entered with pride, arrogance, and insolence. We ask Allah Almighty for well-being.
In those days, the Sublime State sent asking His Excellency As'ad Pasha for camel rennets and ginger roots. Immediately His Excellency the Pasha fetched from the Arab al-Jabla three she-camels that ate nothing but their mother's milk. They were slaughtered and their rennets extracted. His Excellency As'ad Pasha sent them with the ginger roots with three pregnant she-camels accompanied by three eunuchs.
In those days, news reached Damascus that Sa'd al-Din Pasha, who is As'ad Pasha's brother, oppressed the people of Aleppo. He raised prices, and demanded two hundred purses of piastres from them, because the Sardariyya of the Hajj Jarda was directed to him. They refused to give him, a great dispute occurred, Friday prayer was cancelled, and a group of them was killed. The next day, a rotl of bread was ten masari, he called it out for four masari. Meat was thirty the rotl, he called it out for twelve masari. The notables of Aleppo sent a petition to the Sublime State about what happened. We did not know what would happen after.
In early Sha'ban of this year, news reached Damascus that Ibn al-Harfush, Governor of Baalbek, the famous Mutawali Rafidite, arrested the Mufti and his brother, burned them with fire, demolished their house, and cut their vineyards. This malicious Harfush family, may Allah curse it, had years ago also killed Sheikh Yahya, Mufti of Baalbek, famous for knowledge and generosity.
In those days, a man hanged himself in Yilbugha Mosque on a tree in it at night. People woke up and found him hanged, and the reason was not known.
In those days, a garden gate fell on a man in Salihiyya called Sayyid Ibrahim al-Halwani from the Suwayqa neighborhood. They carried him to his house, and he died the second day.
The first of Ramadan of this year was Saturday, confirmed at the sixth hour of the night.
On Monday, the third of Ramadan, the Agha of Kapikulu was killed in the Citadel after Asr. The one who killed him was one of his group by the planning of one of the two dismissed Aghas, because Damascus has three Aghas for Kapikulu: one employed who was killed, and the two dismissed ones turned against him in envy, assassinated him, and his blood went in vain. Muhammad Basha bin Shams was also killed in Wadi al-Qarn and his killer was not known.
On the sixth of Ramadan, the Surra Emini entered Damascus. Eid was Monday and fasting complete.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
In this year, many Persian pilgrims came. They are, according to what they reported, one thousand six hundred Persians, besides Baghdadis and Arabs. This brought comfort to all people in buying and selling. With the Persians came gold rupees, each for thirteen piastres, large and small pearls, stones, minerals, shawls, and other things.
The Mahmal left on Thursday, the eighteenth of Shawwal, and the Hajj left on Friday after repeated calls that no pilgrim should spend the night except outside Bab Allah. The Mutasallim and Baltajiyya left after Asr, and people at night, and the rest on Saturday morning. This is something unprecedented to our knowledge.
In Shawwal during these days, severe unbearable heat occurred, until springs and wells dried up. The Bayt Ras canal, a village of Babbila on the road to Qabr al-Sitt, sank, dried up, and was obliterated, as if it never was. Following the drying of springs and lack of water, an increase of water came, until water became like tahini.
On Wednesday, the eighth of Dhu al-Qi'dah, a man was publicly shamed, said to be forging fake coins. He rode a donkey backwards, his face blackened with soot, tools of work on his chest, and they circled him through the entire city. Despite this, high prices reached their limit: a rotl of meat for twenty-six masari, rice for ten masari, bread for five masari, to the end of what we presented.
In the middle of Dhu al-Qi'dah, the Governor of Aleppo Sa'd al-Din Pasha, brother of As'ad Pasha Ibn al-Azm, arrived in Damascus, Sardar to the Hajj Jarda, and departed with it on Thursday, the first of Dhu al-Hijjah.

Year 1165
Then the year one thousand one hundred and sixty-five entered on Saturday. People rejoiced at its arrival, as on the eve of the crescent heavy rain fell, and they rejoiced, planted, and tilled. Prices began to drop, except that rulers and faces need to inspect creation with mercy and kindness. Hoarders are many, notables silent, and rulers eating. To Allah we belong and to Him we return. Look at the high prices: This year approached with its bounties and blessings, yet a rotl of bread is four masari, dibs four rotls less a third for a piastre, a rotl of ghee a piastre and a half, a rotl of onions four masari, a rotl of garlic seven masari, a rotl of charcoal four masari, and measure on this. The rich are enjoying and the poor are patient.
The historian, may Allah forgive him, said: On Monday, the tenth of Muharram of this year, a decree arrived from the Sublime State that His Excellency Khalil Effendi al-Bakri became Judge in Damascus. They registered the decree, and his son As'ad Effendi al-Bakri sat in his place until his father's arrival as will come.
On Sunday, the twenty-second of Muharram, the Jukhadar of the Noble Hajj arrived, announcing about the Hajj all good, and that the Hajj stood at Arafat on Friday. This is the ninth of the consecutive pilgrimages of His Excellency As'ad Pasha. This never happened to another, and praise be to Allah who gave him.
The next day, the Treasury of Egypt entered Damascus. The historian said: With it was our relative the Sheikh of the Sa'diyya in the Egyptian lands, Sheikh Yahya Effendi al-Jabawi, brother of Sheikh Ibrahim al-Jabawi al-Shaghuri from his father.
On Tuesday, the first of Safar al-Khayr, was the entry of the Syrian Hajj caravan into Damascus. They saw no distress as they reported, except that they encountered in Hediyah large hail, each hailstone weighing sixty dirhams, but no harm resulted from it.
In those days, it reached us that the people of Egypt expelled every stranger, and whoever they found afterwards they looted his money and tortured him severely.
In early Rabi' al-Awwal, Khalil Effendi al-Bakri entered as Judge of Damascus. Some rejoiced and some grieved, thinking he brought matters of change, alteration, and inspection, but none of that happened.
On the eve of Wednesday, the sixteenth of Rabi' al-Awwal, the glorious scholar, Sheikh of the Shafi'is in Damascus, nay Sheikh of Sheikhs of the virtuous among its eminent scholars, our Sheikh and teacher Sheikh Ali Kuzbar passed away. We prayed over him Dhuhr prayer in the Umayyad Mosque, and he was buried in the cemetery of Bab al-Saghir south of Aws bin Aws al-Thaqafi. Before his death he made a will. Among what he willed was fifty piastres to repair the graves around his grave. This was a karamah (miracle) from him, because at the hour of his burial many graves collapsed from the crowding of people surrounding his funeral. May Allah Almighty have mercy on him, and return upon us from his blessings.
On the eve of Tuesday, the last of Rabi' al-Awwal, Sayyid Muhammad son of Sayyid Ahmad, servant of Sidi Abu al-Darda', was found slaughtered in his house inside the Citadel. He had a slave and a Mamluk, and no trace was seen of them. It was said they killed him, and Allah knows best, and he went as if he never was.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
In those days, Hasan Effendi bin Hamza, former Naqib of Ashraf, passed away. The prayer over him was attended by our Governor, ruler of Damascus As'ad Pasha al-Azm, its Judge Khalil Effendi al-Bakri al-Siddiqi, its Mufti Hamid Effendi al-Imadi, its current Naqib Muhammad Effendi al-Ajlani, Ali Effendi al-Muradi, notables of Damascus, and many people. He was buried in the cemetery of Marj al-Dahdah, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him.
The second day, the glorious scholar Imam of the two niches belonging to the Shafi'is, Sheikh al-Masri, passed away. He was the one who brought the Samarmar water, and loved fulfilling needs for Allah's servants. He was buried in Al-Dahdah cemetery, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him.
On the first of Jumada al-Thani, Hasan Chalabi bin al-Safarjalani passed away. He was among the leaders in Damascus. On this day, three Sheikhs of guilds died in Damascus: Sheikh Abd al-Qadir Sheikh of sweet-makers (Halwaniyya), Sheikh of barbers Usta Muhammad al-Bushi, and Sheikh of Kavuk-makers (Qawaqjiya) Usta Muhammad.
On Thursday, the third of Jumada al-Thani, hail fell in Damascus. One was weighed and came to seventy dirhams. This year has abundant rains, bounties, and blessings. A grain of wheat sprouted twenty-two stalks/ears. Someone even reported to me that a grain of wheat sprouted on the roof of his house, and he found it after transplanting it to be twenty-two stalks i.e., ears. Despite that, everything is expensive: a rotl of ghee in days of its abundance ten ounces for a piastre, dibs three rotls for a piastre, onions five rotls for a piastre. Everything according to prices we presented, and judgment is for Allah.
In this period, His Excellency Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha bin al-Azm, Governor of Damascus, paved the Maydan road from Bab al-Musalla to Bab Allah, and did not oppress anyone with that nor take anything from anyone.
In early Rajab, the Prince son of Zahir Umar, ruler of Tiberias and Acre, arrived. His Excellency As'ad Pasha received him through Musa Kikhiya, bestowed a robe on him, honored him, and comforted him regarding his father, because there were matters between him and his father Zahir Umar, so the Pasha reconciled them.
In those days, Khalil Effendi al-Bakri, the aforementioned Judge, built the minaret above the Maristan.
In these days, a Kapici came from the Sublime State summoning Sayyid Muhammad Effendi al-Muradi to appear before His Excellency the Grand Sultan, and to be brought honored, and to give him forty purses. He was given the mentioned sum and carried in a Roman litter. The notables and grandees of Damascus presented him with great gifts of mounts, money, and luxurious clothes. The notables went out to bid him farewell with His Excellency the Governor of Damascus Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha al-Azm. His departure from Damascus was on Monday, the ninth of Rajab the Unique of this year.
In these days, Ahmad Effendi, Diwan Effendi of the Pasha, passed away. He is the one who built the palace in the Ahmadiyya wall in Suq al-Arwam. He died without child or heir. It was said his estate reached seven hundred purses, mostly gold cash. His Excellency the Pasha took them, and Allah does what He wills.
In those days, the waters of the Shaghour district were disrupted. Much money was imposed on its owners. They complained to His Excellency As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus, may Allah preserve him. He ordered that nothing be taken from anyone, rather he ordered paying fifteen hundred piastres from his treasury to fix the water and run the stream.
The historian Al-Budayri, may Allah Almighty forgive him, said: I went out to visit Sayyida Zaynab with my son Mustafa, reciting Allah's words on our way, until we reached the Lady and entered her shrine. We viewed the building constructed by Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha al-Azm in it this year. He made inside the harem two palaces, an Iwan, eastern chambers, utilities, and other things that immortalized his mention there. We found His Excellency the Pasha's cousin Mustafa Bey, may Allah preserve him, had decorated its walls and ceilings and improved its structure, and began building the bath in this year while we were there. May Allah Almighty reward them both for this charitable work with the best reward, Amen.
On the first night of Sha'ban, His Excellency Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha traveled to the Dawra. On the second night of his travel, a woman was killed in the early night between Al-Suwayqa district and Qabr Atika district, and her killer was not verified.
Ramadan was proven Thursday. The Deputy of Politics was Musa Kikhiya, and the Judge of the city was Khalil Effendi al-Bakri. Prices of bread and others as you see: a rotl of bread three, four, and five masari, a ghirara of wheat twelve piastres, a rotl of meat twenty masari, a rotl of rice ten masari in its season days, dibs three and a third rotls for a piastre, an ounce [of oil?] a masriyyah and a piece, a rotl of onions eight masari, firewood a rotl a masriyyah, oak a qintar one hundred ten masari. No one asks and no grandee speaks. Corruption is much and the Master is Aware.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
In this month in the Umayyad Mosque, a man sat counting gold he had. A man came and snatched them in front of hundreds of people, and ran fast. Their owner shouted, so some political aides caught him, he gave him some gold and he let him go.
In this month also, a man carried his son, and on his head were some dinars. A thief followed him until the carrier of the child entered an alley, snatched the dinars and skullcap and went.
On the eve of Saturday, the tenth of Ramadan, after the doorman of the Umayyad sanctuary closed the doors, he slept. The muezzins came and knocked on the mosque door. He got up to open for them and found his clothes missing. He informed them, so they entered, closed, and searched the sanctuary all of them, but found no one. The strange thing is all doors were closed. Then they went towards the tomb, and found eight silver lamps missing and one gold lamp, and no adversary was known for them.
On the seventh of Ramadan the Blessed, the Surra Emini procession came from Istanbul.
On Thursday in the middle of Ramadan, His Excellency Vizier As'ad Pasha entered Damascus while he was absent in the Dawra. He is, praise be to Allah, in utmost health and safety.
On Saturday, the seventeenth of Ramadan, the Baltajiyya came from Istanbul with twenty-two Roman litters, and with them the son of the Grand Vizier dismissed from the Vizierate this year, with the Queen and a senior eunuch. They reported that the Sublime State is shaky.
On Friday was the day of Eid al-Fitr. A great tremor occurred on that day, which was a sedition between the Maghrebis and the boys of Al-Shaghour. It calmed down, praise be to Allah, without anyone being killed.
On Monday, the fourth of Eid al-Fitr, a young man drowned in the tunnel of Al-Rabwa and no trace appeared for him.
On the eve of Thursday, the fifth of Shawwal, Ibrahim Agha Ibn Qawasar was killed. He was shot in his house in Qabr Atika, and his killer was not known.
On Sunday, the seventeenth of Shawwal, As'ad Pasha al-Azm, may Allah preserve him, departed with the procession of the Noble Mahmal. It was the tenth year of his consecutive pilgrimages with the Syrian caravan as Amir and for Damascus of the Levant as Vizier. On that day the Aleppo caravan came, and two days before it the Persian caravan came, which was small compared to the year before. They stayed in Al-Kharab and Al-Suwayqa. On the nineteenth of Shawwal, the Syrian Hajj caravan marched from Damascus in safety intending the Sacred House of Allah.
After days, His Excellency Muhammad Agha the Mutasallim called out regarding meat, a rotl for eighteen masari, nailed a group of butchers, accepted neither bribe nor gift, and was just in his rule, may Allah Almighty grant him success, until the poor began praying for him openly. After a while, he priced all goods and was strict, and began taking the hand of everyone who complained to him. May Allah reward him with good.
In that year charcoal was hoarded. The Mutasallim inspected and priced, but that availed nothing. No one reached charcoal except the strong like Kapikulu and Dalati. The Mutasallim found no helper in this regard.

Year 1166
Then the year one thousand one hundred and sixty-six entered on Tuesday or Wednesday. May Allah make it a year of good, blessing, and mercy upon us and upon all Allah's creation.
On its first, i.e., first of Muharram, a judge from the sons of Turks named Salih Mulla entered for Damascus. He stayed in the house of Ali Agha bin al-Tarjuman near Bab al-Qal'a, and judgment from the old court called Al-Kubra ceased.
In those days, the tower of the Citadel fell, taking the whole wall from its door, and so on to the end of the tower from the Qibla side. No one was killed except a man from the Citadel.
In those days, rain fell like mouths of waterskins for three consecutive days, destroying most raisin drying grounds and ruining threshing floors.
In these days in the first ten of Muharram, the Mutasallim of Damascus hanged three persons from thieves on the grape vine tree in Al-Marja in front of the Takiyya gate.
In the middle of Muharram, glad tidings came to Damascus: a decree confirming His Excellency Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha as Governor of Damascus.
On the eve of Monday, the eve of the twentieth of Muharram, the Mutasallim hanged a thief in Al-Suwayqa and cut off the hand of a pickpocket man.
At the end of Muharram, the Jukhadar's writer came, and reported that the Hajj in this year went and returned via the road of Al-Far'i. Arabs came out against them, they endured great hardship, a huge massacre occurred, and a decrease happened in the Hajj and the army, especially among the Maghrebis.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
In that year, the Kapuci-lar Aghasi and the Sheikh of Zabadani died. The Pasha hanged Sayyid Hasan, Sheikh of the youth of Bab al-Musalla, and also killed a group of wretches. The Noble Hajj entered on Tuesday, the fifth of Safar. The Amir al-Hajj As'ad Pasha entered with the Mahmal procession on Wednesday.
In the middle of Rabi' al-Awwal, the ruler warned that broken flus and lead ones should not circulate. The next day, the crier called out regarding sound flus, every twelve for a masriyyah after they were every twenty-four for a masriyyah, and that only the Constantini should circulate. People faced great distress, and most of the city closed down. Then the ruler's crier called out every twenty-four for a masriyyah, returning them to their first state.
But praise and favor be to Allah, people are in safety and security, cheapness and prosperity in all goods except meat, for a rotl is twenty-eight masari. As for others, a rotl of bread three masari and two and a half, a ghirara of wheat fifteen piastres or less. On this, praise be to Allah, you can measure.
On the third of Rabi' al-Thani, the righteous servant Sheikh Mustafa al-Kurdi, from the sons of Turks and Afghans, speaking Turkish, Kurdish, and Afghani, passed away. He was of amazing righteousness, always armed with full weapons, carrying them night and day, not sleeping except carrying them. If he entered the bath, he entered with full gear. He spoke little, not speaking to anyone. Sometimes he would speak and curse in Turkish. On the day of his death, he had a great funeral, and was buried in Marj al-Dahdah, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him.
In those days of this year, His Excellency As'ad Pasha began building the Qaysariyya in Al-Bazuriyya, whose equal is rare in the world. That was after demolishing two Qaysariyyas, houses, and shops, making it one Qaysariyya with this description that has no equal.
On Wednesday, the ninth of Rabi' al-Thani, the wall of Sheikh Arudak Mosque west of Salihiyya fell on the Imam of the mentioned Mosque and three persons with him. They all died, may Allah forgive them. Strangely, these four, each one's name was Muhammad, which is a strange coincidence. They were buried in one day.
At the end of Rabi' al-Thani, an adolescent boy tied a mare's halter to his belt, and sat performing ablution at the river of Al-Qadam village at Qubbat al-Asali. The mare panicked and began running with the boy tied to its halter, dragging and kicking the boy until it reached Bab Allah. They caught the mare and found the boy crushed, cut, and dead. The boy was the son of Ahmad Basha al-Sahhar al-Qubaybati, and the mare was his father's. They informed His Excellency As'ad Pasha, may Allah preserve him, and he ordered his burial, and did not harm anyone.
In those days, the Treasury of Egypt came and stayed for days then traveled. In those days, thieves looted the shrines of Companions and Saints. On the first of Rajab, they uprooted the window of Sidi Bilal al-Habashi, took its iron, a brocade cloth that was on his coffin, two pieces of silk, two rugs, and other things. They took the window of Sheikh Abd al-Jabbar son of Sidi Abd al-Qadir al-Jilani, his shrine is west of Bab al-Saghir. The cloth of the coffin of Sidi Ubayy south of Sheikh Arslan's cemetery was taken.
On the second of Rajab of this year, His Excellency Vizier Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus, headed out wanting to raid the Arabs of Al-Balqa. He took with him from the village men, the peasants, one thousand one hundred peasants. He brought soldiers from Homs, Hama, Ma'arra, Druze Mountain, Matawila, Nablus, Jerusalem, and Safed, besides the Sardiya Arabs and others. He went out with great wealth. Markets closed those days, women were prevented from going out, and matters became grave.
Then during this month, news arrived that His Excellency the Pasha marched with the army to above Al-Balqa, entered a place called Al-Wkr, defeated Ibn Adwan and his Arabs, and the army looted them completely. The Pasha went to the Dawra from there.
In this year, Ramadan was proven by sighting, so we fasted Monday. On the eve of the tenth of Ramadan, the Pasha came from the Dawra, and the army came with the Kikhiya two days later.
In this month, a stranger pilgrim was lost in Khan al-Haramayn in Bab al-Barid. They accused a man from the sons of Turks, a Ghalyanji, arrested him, tortured him, took his money, and released him. In this month, many killed men and women appeared and no one asked about them. Everything is available and high prices play in all goods. Damascus was filled with all types of creation, and most places became full. Eid al-Fitr was Wednesday.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On Tuesday, the fourteenth of Shawwal, the Noble Mahmal left with the lofty procession and the Perilous Amir Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha. It was the eleventh Hajj of his consecutive pilgrimages.
In those days, two Tughs (standards) came to Mustafa Bey bin Isma'il Pasha al-Azm, brother of As'ad Pasha, to be protector of the Jarda with his brother Sa'd al-Din Pasha, two Amirs in the Jarda travel.
One day before their departure, the Damascus Kapikulu rose entirely with weapons, made a gathering, and the Yamak rose against the Artaliyya. This sedition was because of a man who became a Kapikulu and they did not accept or approve him. Markets closed, bullets were fired, and they wounded each other. The matter was not resolved except by invalidating the man from the Ojak, and dismissing the Odabashi and Usta.
Eid al-Adha this year was Sunday. News appeared in those days about changing the Sultan and the coming of Ahmad Pasha Ibn al-Qaltaqji. The Kapikulu were confused and disturbed, then it appeared the matter was a lie with no basis. They burned the wood (bonfire?) and circled in the markets. On Friday, while people were in prayer at the end of Dhu al-Hijjah, the sun eclipsed.
In those days, news came that Muhammad Pasha, Governor of Sidon, died. According to reports, he was unjust, tyrannical, confiscating people's wealth, until the people of Sidon fled to all lands.

Year 1167
Then the year one thousand one hundred and sixty-seven entered on Saturday. On this day, the Judge of Damascus Salih Mulla traveled seeking Istanbul. On the seventh of Muharram, the new Judge arrived, and stayed in the Nuriyya Court called Mahkamat al-Bab.
On the eighteenth, Ahmad Agha bin Sinan was killed in Bab al-Musalla. He was from a village near Qatana.
On the eve of Friday, the twentieth of Muharram, the remnant of eminent scholars, Mufti of the Shafi'i Masters, and the most eloquent to speak Arabic, Sheikh Muhammad Effendi al-Ghazzi passed away. He was buried in Marj al-Dahdah, mercy of Allah be upon him and upon the Muslim dead.
On Tuesday, the twenty-fourth of Muharram, the Jukhadar of the Noble Hajj arrived bringing glad tidings of every general good. During these days, the confirmation of Damascus came for His Excellency Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus.
On Friday, the fifth of Safar al-Khayr, the Syrian Hajj caravan entered in health and safety better than every year. The pilgrims reported they never performed a Hajj like it in abundant cheapness, plentiful water, safety, and security. Pilgrims did not decrease except rare individuals. The Amir al-Hajj impaled four thieves from the sons of Damascus. With them, the Turbadar and administrator of Sultan Ibrahim bin Adham Mosque passed away.
The next day, Saturday, the Noble Mahmal and lofty procession entered with the Kikhiyas and Pashas. The first of them was Mustafa Pasha bin Isma'il Pasha al-Azm, brother of Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha. After him his brother Sa'd al-Din Pasha al-Azm. After him their brother the Great Vizier Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha in a crowded regiment, army, and legions. The third day, the Treasury of Egypt entered, with eight loads. People watched three spectacles on three consecutive days: day of Hajj entry, day of Mahmal entry, and day of Egypt Treasury entry.
In that year in the month of Muharram al-Haram, the Qaysariyya of As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus, was completed, the like of which was not made in all lands of Islam. Its building was completed after a year and two months.
The historian said: It reached me that he spent on it every day for materials and wages one thousand one hundred piastres. But as the saying goes: May Allah reward expansion with every good.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On the eve of Thursday, the nineteenth of Safar al-Khayr, three days into Kanun al-Awwal (December), in the third hour of the night, a light earthquake occurred in Damascus. Due to it, some places in the Government Palace fell on a group, killing a Muslim man and a Christian man. That month's rain was very heavy, followed, Allah Almighty willing, by much good.
In this month, Sheikh Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Sawwar, Sheikh of the Mahya, and Sheikh Khalil bin al-Bakri passed away in his house in Bab Tuma, and they held [a funeral?] for him in the Umayyad.
On the eighteenth of the month of Safar, Friday after Asr, Sheikh Ahmad al-Chalabi, Imam of Al-Sinaniyya Mosque for the Shafi'i Masters, passed away to Allah Almighty's mercy. The historian said: This Imam was a leader in every art, smiling, virtuous, blessed, residing in Al-Addas Mosque with Mulla Ilyas, sanctified be his secret, never leaving the Mulla night or day. He was buried in Bab al-Saghir near Mulla Ilyas, may Allah Almighty have mercy on them both.
In those days also, Sheikh Yahya bin Mahasin passed away, may Allah have mercy on him.
On Monday, the twenty-second of the month of Safar, Sa'd al-Din al-Maghrebi, a servant in the house of the Khanum daughter of Sulayman Pasha, quarrelled with a man from the Orta personnel. He hit the Artali killing him, and wounded the Khanum's eunuch after the Maghrebi wounded him twice. When it reached His Excellency Vizier As'ad Pasha, he ordered his killing immediately, so they strangled him in those days without proof or lawsuit.
In the middle of the winter forty days (Marba'aniyyat al-Shita'), a rock fell in the Qanawat river, opposite Wadi Kaywan, blocking the river. It was cut off for three days and nights. They took out the rock piece by piece, and found it to be an ancient tomb of the tombs of wise men.
In the month of Rabi' ..., the Pasha returned the Sardar to the lands. They began capturing Arabs of the mountain, killing them, and bringing their heads to Damascus.
In the month of Jumada ..., His Excellency As'ad Pasha renewed the mosque in front of the Kharayzatiyya coffeehouse, improved its appearance and furnishing, and built water canals for some of its shops near the house of Al-Safarjalani.
In late Rajab, a confirmation came for the year sixty-eight, which is for thirteen years of his rule, may Allah preserve him, as Amir of Damascus and Amir of the Hajj of Islam. He was just to the elite and commoners, kind to scholars, poor, and orphans without injustice or aggression. He built many places inside the city and outside, Madrasas, mosques, and other aspects of good and charity, may Allah reward him with good.
On Monday, the fifth of Rajab, His Excellency As'ad Pasha went out to the Dawra, and left Musa Kikhiya as Mutasallim there. Mid-Sha'ban the Blessed was Thursday, and the first of Ramadan was proven Saturday. Prices are very high: a rotl of meat twenty-four masari, a rotl of bread four and five masari, a rotl of rice ten masari, a rotl of cakes twelve masari, a rotl of dibs fifteen masari, an ounce of ghee six masari in season days, an ounce of oil three masari and a half, likewise soap, an ounce of green cheese two masriyyahs, an ounce of Qarisheh three masari, a rotl of Hamwi apricots six masari despite being plentiful, Baladi apricots three masari and a half with its abundance. In summary, everything is expensive, even leeches people use to extract blood, and Qasarmal which comes out of bath fuel. The command is for Allah.
On the twelfth of Shawwal, His Excellency Vizier Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha marched with the Mahmal in the great procession for the Noble Hajj. This year was the thirteenth of his consecutive pilgrimages and his emirate which never happened for another. In this year, they passed Wadi al-Laymun on the way out, their standing (at Arafat) was Friday, and they returned from the Sultani road.
On the twenty-fifth of Muharram, the Hajj Jukhadar entered and announced good news. On the fifth of Safar, the Noble Hajj entered in the best condition.
In these days, a man from the simple-minded Majadhib (attracted ones) passed away. He was a hero among heroes, believed in by the people of Damascus, revealing with his words, and it happens as he says. His name was Sheikh Khalil al-Bayyad. Notables of Damascus went out in his funeral, even its ruler the Mutasallim Musa Kikhiya walked behind it, may Allah have mercy on him.

Year 1168
Then the year one thousand one hundred and sixty-eight entered. Its first Muharram was Monday the Blessed. May Allah make it a year of good and blessing upon us and all Muslims.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On Friday, the last of Safar, a Kapici arrived from Istanbul, reporting the death of His Excellency Sultan Mahmud Khan on a Friday while people were in prayer, and his brother sat in his place, Sultan Uthman Khan, and the Khutba is in his name. The city of Damascus shook from this news, and people remained hesitant in settling down, until Thursday the tenth of Rabi' al-Thani, a great Kapici came from the Abode of Sultanate with a great decree that the owner of the Khutba in all lands of Islam is Sultan Uthman Khan. He ordered Damascus to be decorated for three days. It was decorated a decoration the like of which was not heard. May Allah Almighty preserve this Ottoman State until the end of time. Amen.
In this year, smallpox spread among all people, even elders and old women, and many children died in it.
In early Jumada al-Ula, the Bayraqdar of Tafakjiya was slaughtered in the small Khan opposite Hammam al-Malika. His slaughterer was not known, and nothing was taken from his money. A killed person was found in these days in the river, and a killed person in the cemetery, and elsewhere too. We ask Allah Almighty for a good end.
In the middle of Jumada al-Ula, a confirmation came to Mustafa Pasha brother of Sa'd al-Din Pasha bin al-Azm for Sidon. No healing news came to his brother As'ad Pasha regarding the rule of Damascus, and the wait prolonged for him. High prices in everything, even soil, cinder, stones, iron, wood, and other building materials. With total effort one gets a master or carpenter, the wage of one is a dinar and not found. Lime and adobe are not found, and so on. Breaths are constricted, things exceeded measure, and the Pasha and those around him collect money in purses. He called out for meat and it was not found, called out for soap and it dissipated, called out for oil. He had purposes, matters, and rulings that crush the liver. Help is sought from Allah, the Single, the Eternal.
On the nineteenth of Jumada al-Ula, news appeared that a woman killed her husband with a group of wretches, claiming he sleeps with his Mamluk and not with her. After killing him, they buried him in the house corridor. The victim belonged to the Kurds, had a coffeehouse in Suq al-Khayl, and his name was Darwish Agha. The Kurds rose on their leg in Suq al-Khayl. A small boy who was present and aware of his killing and burial came and guided them to his murder place and house. They went and arrested everyone. They found the Pasha's gunner (Topci) Khalil Agha, the wife's brother, and another man. They came to the gunner and cut him to pieces, killed the man and the wife's brother. As for the woman, they took her and drowned her in the drowning place of Al-Bahsa in Barada river. They did not ask for rulers, and the ruler did not interfere with them. We ask Allah Almighty for near relief.
In those days, His Excellency As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus, began restoring the Umayyad Mosque. It reached me that he bought carpets, i.e., furnishings, for four purses. May Allah reward him with good.
On the ninth of Jumada al-Ula on Tuesday, great rain and huge snow fell. Waters rose until Barada river overflowed, the increase reached below the Citadel, and walked to the Amara neighborhood, but praise be to Allah it did not harm anyone or buildings.
In those days, sedition occurred between the Arabs of Sham and the Arabs of Anaza.
In the month of Rajab, As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus, sent an army to the Arab al-Fadl, looting their wealth, cattle, and some of their families. In those days, the Pasha hanged a porter from the Bahsa neighborhood, said to have strangled a neighbor of his.
In the middle of the month of Rajab, the confirmation of His Excellency As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus, came. It was the thirteenth year of his rule and Emirate of Hajj. In this month, His Excellency the mentioned Governor of Damascus went out to the Dawra, and appointed Musa Kikhiya as Mutasallim in his place for Damascus.
The crescent of Ramadan this year was confirmed on the eve of Tuesday. Lamps were lit in minarets. They prayed Tarawih before firing cannons, which were not fired until after two hours.
In these days, the government removed Prince Haydar bin Harfush from the town of Baalbek. He refused to leave it and ordered everyone in it to depart, and whoever stayed after three days his money and family would be looted. So they departed after he burned their houses and vineyards, and scattered to lands and villages. He resided there as a rebel. Then Prince Hussein bin Harfush guaranteed Baalbek, and most people of Baalbek returned without the slightest incident.

Year 1169

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
Then the year one thousand one hundred and sixty-nine entered on Sunday. High prices exist in Damascus as we presented. The Jukhadar came on the twenty-seventh of Muharram, the Writer came the second day of Safar, and on the sixth day of it the Noble Hajj entered. The pilgrims reported that this year was fertile, and the Amir al-Hajj took them via other than the Sultani road, so severe thirst befell the Hajj, until one thousand five hundred humans perished in one day.
At the end of Rabi' al-Thani, a confirmation came to Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha in Damascus. It is the fourteenth year of his rule of Damascus and consecutive Emirate of the Noble Hajj which never happened to another. That night great snow fell in Damascus the like of which was not seen for years.
In those days, a Kapici came to Hussein Bey bin Makki, Governor of Gaza, with a Firman to be Pasha in Jerusalem and repair the water of Jerusalem, and to collect the money of the Dawra by order of the State.
The fasting of Ramadan this year was on Sunday. In Jumada al-Ula, great snow fell in Damascus, stayed for days, and demolished many places. In those days, a Kapici came with the return of Jerusalem to As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus.
In that month, news came that the Arabs of Hijaz are besieging the City of the Messenger, peace be upon him. It has been under siege for about two months. They demolished what is around it, cut its palms, and tightened on its people. They are now in distress and tightness not preceded nor heard of since the era of Jahiliyyah. This situation reached the Sublime State, may Allah Almighty support it. It sent to the ruler of Damascus As'ad Pasha al-Azm to prepare to fight them with men and a dragging army, and to his brother Mustafa Pasha likewise, and to his brother Sa'd al-Din Pasha likewise, and to be governor in Jeddah, and to take soldiers with him and assist his two brothers.
In that year, His Excellency Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha al-Azm ordered the restoration and repair of Yilbugha Mosque. He made an endowment and stipends for it after renewing latrines and other things in it. He also ordered repairing the Yaghushiyya Mosque under the Citadel. A wall from it had fallen on a woman and men. He obligated some of his specialists to repair it from his own money because he was wealthy. In early Rajab, the building of the Shaghour coffeehouse opposite Sheikh Al-Saruji, may Allah be pleased with him, was completed. In those days, two coffeehouses were also built in Bab al-Sarija and a coffeehouse in front of Bab al-Musalla.
On Friday of Sha'ban, Mustafa Bey bin Mardam Bey passed away. He was among the notables of Damascus and families whose righteousness the people of Damascus testified to, because he loved good and did it, did not approach rulers, and harmed no one. He was buried in their cemetery at his grandfather Lala Mustafa Pasha, at the bottom of Suq al-Sinaniyya.
Then the blessed Ramadan came, and they confirmed it Sunday, and we fasted it completely. The Hajj marched intending Hijaz on the eighteenth of Shawwal. On that day, Abdullah Effendi Zade, Judge of Damascus, passed away, and was buried next to Sidi Bilal al-Habashi, may Allah be pleased with him. On this day, they found a boy strangled in Barada river, and later his father appeared to be a Khawaja in Suq al-Silah.
On Sunday, the third of Dhu al-Hijjah, Sa'd al-Din Pasha, Governor of Tripoli, entered as Sardar of the Jarda after receiving his dismissal from Tripoli. Saturday was the day of Arafah (Waqfa) of Eid al-Adha in Damascus. At the end of Dhu al-Hijjah on Friday, the preacher of the Umayyad Muhammad Sa'id Effendi bin Mahasin passed away and was buried in Bab al-Saghir.

Year 1170
Then the year one thousand one hundred and seventy entered on Saturday in a horoscope of blessing, joy, and happiness, Allah willing. But high prices exist in goods and others as we mentioned, so no return or repetition.
In these days, Mustafa Pasha, brother of As'ad Pasha al-Azm, was separated from Sidon and the Wilaya of Adana was directed to him. In those days, the Qanawat river was cut off after the Raisin Festival. In mid-Muharram, the Judge of Damascus Muhammad Effendi came from Istanbul. In these days, they nailed a baker at Bab al-Jabiya.
On the twenty-seventh of Muharram, the Hajj Jukhadar Al-Dali Ali Bash entered with a group, and announced the news that His Excellency the Pasha and pilgrims are safe. On Tuesday, the writers of Hama and Aleppo came. On Wednesday, a Christian came with some letters, and reported that the Damascus writer was wounded by Arabs. In those days, the sky brought rain like mouths of waterskins, until people thought the Hajj had drowned. It was at the station of Al-Sanamayn. The entry of Hajj was delayed from its time about a week.
On Tuesday, the twelfth of Safar, the Noble Hajj entered. The next day, the Amir al-Hajj and Governor of Damascus Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha al-Azm entered in the procession of Hajj and the Noble Mahmal. This is the fourteenth year as we presented of his consecutive years of Hajj which was not known for another. May Allah perpetuate the days of his existence, Amen.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
In this year, His Excellency As'ad Pasha reconciled between the people of the Noble Medina and the Arabs who besieged it, after giving them about one hundred purses of money. All pilgrims thanked him for this deed, may Allah Almighty reward him with all good, Amen. In this year, a decrease also occurred in camels and people. They reported that in the station of Abar al-Ghanam (Sheep Wells), more than one thousand seven hundred souls died in one day from intense heat (Shawb). In another station (Qonaq), seven hundred souls, besides those who died gradually.
In these days, measles (Humayra) occurred among children in Damascus, and many of them died.
On Monday, the thirteenth of Rabi' al-Awwal, His Excellency the Sultan gifted His Excellency the Amir al-Hajj As'ad Pasha with a Kapici Bashi a caftan and a great sword with a great Firman containing much honoring for the referenced Vizier.
On the eve of Friday, our Sheikh Ibrahim al-Jabawi al-Sa'di al-Shaghuri, Sheikh of the prayer rug (Sajjada) of the Sa'diyya Order and administrator of the Umayyad Mosque, passed away. He had traveled to Istanbul and met three Sultans: Sultan Ahmad, Sultan Mahmud, and Sultan Uthman. He received good and favor, after a secret and proof appeared for him. He left many successors in Rum, Egypt, Aleppo, and Damascus. He reached a great status with total humility, sitting in coffeehouses and greeting the big and small. The day of his death was a witnessed day, and he was buried at his grandfather Sheikh Hasan al-Jabawi, may Allah have mercy on him.
At the end of Rabi' al-Awwal of this year, which is the year one thousand one hundred and seventy, the Judge of Damascus died and was buried in Bab al-Saghir, and had a great funeral.
On the seventh day past of Tishrin al-Thani (November), heavy rains fell, followed by severe cold and dry wind, until waters froze in pools and basins, trees dried, and rocks cracked. It continued for some twenty days. Lemon, citron, bitter orange, and other trees dried up. It continued some twenty days, until you find them in roads like rocks. Many wild animals, dogs, and birds died. It reached me that a person had chickens, and in one day twenty-two chickens died despite protecting them. As for the wilderness, do not ask what ice and cold did in them; much livestock and sheep died. Many children and women of the Arabs died. It reached me that the Norias of Hama stopped, and mills too, and markets closed. In summary, a terrifying cold, disturbing freeze, and terrible ice, perhaps not heard of for years.
The historian Al-Budayri, may Allah forgive him, said: On Thursday, mid-Rabi' al-Thani of this year, Damascus was directed to Raghib Pasha, separated from the city of Aleppo. On the eve of Wednesday, the last of Rabi' al-Thani, news came with a messenger (Najjab) to His Excellency Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha, Governor of Damascus, that he was dismissed and appointed to Aleppo. The second day of his dismissal, he sent for his Mutasallim Musa Agha, dressed him in a precious fur, and set him up as Mutasallim of Damascus. He showed that news came from the State to be Kikhiya of Raghib Pasha, to handle matters of Hajj and Dawra, and that glad tidings came that after the end of the Hajj year he is Governor of Jeddah and Pasha with two Tughs. So Musa Kikhiya received the rule of Damascus.
As'ad Pasha released everyone in the prisons. There were many in prisons from four, five, and ten years. As'ad Pasha stayed in Damascus frequenting the Government Saraya until Friday, the fifteenth of Jumada al-Ula. A Kapici came to him with the Firman of rule in the city of Aleppo, and glad tidings of two Tughs for Musa Kikhiya, and that Raghib Pasha separated from Aleppo has attained the Grand Vizierate and headed to Istanbul, and that Damascus was directed to Hussein Pasha bin Makki residing in the city of Gaza.
Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha stayed until Monday, and departed in safety heading to the city of Aleppo, after ordering the reform of the two Ojaks, and to place in every junction a group of Janissaries and a group of Kapikulu, and to place over them in every station (Qulla) an Onbashi. News spread that the coming Governor to Damascus is of bad character, unjust and tyrannical. The Kapikulu feared the Janissaries and all the entourage of As'ad Pasha. They began engaging in gossip. Some fools from the people of Al-Haqla and Al-Maydan rose, but their elders turned them back. Great fear and rumors occurred in the city, until the Kapikulu vacated their houses, and shop owners vacated their shops from all markets.
The first ruling of Musa Kikhiya the Mutasallim was ordering that all Manazil (guardhouses?) in the neighborhoods from twenty or thirty years be built by the people of their district. The city was disturbed a disturbing disturbance. On that day, the Pasha hanged a young man from the boys of Al-Suwayqa called Ibn Sumratayn, so tremors decreased and people felt safe.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On Tuesday and the eve of Wednesday after Maghrib, news spread reaching the Saraya that Ahmad al-Qaltaqji, who was among the heads of the Zarbawat who fled and rebelled in the Druze Mountain as we mentioned before, attacked Damascus on the eve of Wednesday. What an ominous night for the people of Damascus from the abundance of fear, terror, sleeplessness, and evacuation of houses and shops that overwhelmed them. Barricades were lined up in all gates. It was a night, from its terror, like the Night of Resurrection. The people of Damascus did not taste sleep in it at all, waiting for the break of dawn. When it appeared to them, they found nothing of what they imagined, and the news was false.
On Thursday, the fifth of Jumada al-Thani, with Dhuhr Adhan, was the entry of Hussein Pasha bin Makki to Damascus, separated from the city of Gaza which is his homeland. He entered with a great procession full of Effendis, notables of Damascus, Janissaries all cavalry, and Kapikulu all infantry, in complete gear, adorned weapons, and comprehensive decoration. Commoners and creation stood praying for him, shouting and seeking help from the oppression of Damascus notables and high prices.
The next day, Effendis and notables came to the Saraya to greet the Pasha. People and commoners stood in their way. When they passed them to enter the Saraya, the commoners rose with screaming and clamor, shouted at them and said: Go back, no blessing of Allah upon you, you are hypocrites and help rulers in oppressing the poor and needy. They increased in cursing and insulting them, and stoned them with stones. It became a disturbing situation. So the Pasha opened the door of justice and inspection of the subjects, until a rotl of bread became three masari. Then he busied himself with injustice like his predecessors, so prices returned to their first state: like a rotl of bread for five and six masari, until a freeze came, which is painful severe cold, leaving no fruit in the month of Adhar but burning it. On the tenth of Rajab, a freeze occurred the like of which was not heard, destroying what remained if anything remained of fruits.
On the seventeenth of Rajab, Wednesday, the glorious scholar, the Faradi (expert in inheritance law) Sheikh Abdullah al-Basrawi al-Shafi'i, the erudite of his time in every art especially the science of inheritance, passed away and was buried in the tomb of Sheikh Arslan, may Allah have mercy on him. In this noble month also, a man was killed in Al-Maydan, and three slaughtered persons were found in the Baramika cemetery. On the twentieth of Rajab, the Maghrebis attacked the Pasha, then shot at the commoners, killing about ten men and burning places. In these days, two slaughtered women were found in the hill of Bab al-Saghir. In this month also, sedition occurred between Maghrebis and Levend Kurds. About fifteen men from both sides were killed, Damascus closed down, then it ended in reconciliation.
On the twenty-seventh of Rajab, Hussein Pasha, Governor of Damascus, hanged a man from Al-Maydan accused of Haram (immorality/theft?), who had previously killed his mother by slaughtering.
The historian Al-Budayri, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said: In these days, news came that Al-Hajj As'ad Pasha bin al-Azm, Governor of Aleppo, received a Firman to march to Egypt as Governor. The people of Aleppo rebelled with him, and said we want no other, and wrote to the Sublime State about that. Then after days, the confirmation of Aleppo came for As'ad Pasha bin al-Azm, and for his brother Sa'd al-Din Pasha the position of Marash, and for his brother Mustafa Pasha the position of Mosul. Each one went to his position, and Mustafa Pasha sent his harem and children to Damascus.
In early Sha'ban, His Excellency Hussein Pasha, Governor of Damascus, went out to the Dawra, and set up Hussein Agha Alay Bey of Sipahis as Mutasallim in his place. He was just, did not oppress, and did not transgress against anyone. Before the Pasha's departure, he ordered the two Ojaks to reconcile and leave corruption and obstinacy, and handed over to them the lands and servants. He stationed Mustafa Agha al-Za'faranji, elder and chief of Kapikulu Tafakji Bashi, at the Saraya gate, after he guaranteed upon himself the reform of the city.
Ramadan entered on Thursday, and with it entered the greatest high prices in Damascus in all items. A ghirara of wheat reached fifty piastres, a rotl of bread from seven masari to twelve masari, after the highest bread was three masari a rotl. A rotl of rice fourteen masari, dibs likewise, onions also. A mudd of lentils, likewise chickpeas, mung beans, kidney beans, and bulgur thirty masari. A mudd of barley twelve masari, an ounce of garlic two masriyyahs. In summary, everything is expensive with lack of means and lack of movement.
