book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On the eve of Monday, the twelfth of Ramadan, a great sedition occurred between the Janissary Corps and the Kapikulu Corps, the likes of which had not been witnessed for a long time. The Dalatiyya, Kurds, and Mosulis aided the Kapikulu. Each group besieged a neighborhood. Victory belonged to the Janissaries after they fired cannons at them from the Citadel for two days and a night. A group of commoners and a few Janissaries were killed. However, many of the Kapikulu and their followers were killed after they besieged the Bab al-Sarija neighborhood, took possession of it, and destroyed some houses and shops therein. They also besieged the al-Shaghour neighborhood, to the point that they were on the verge of taking it, when the Naqib Hamza Effendi and some Sheikhs came and reconciled between them. Then, after the third day, they differed again.
On the twentieth of Ramadan, Hussein Pasha, the Governor of Sham (Damascus), arrived from the Dawra (tour of duty) but did not make a move. Eid al-Fitr was on Wednesday.
In the first ten days of Shawwal, Mustafa Agha bin Ali Effendi al-Daftari arrived from Istanbul with the rank of Agha over the Janissaries. He entered in an 'Arada, meaning a procession, never before witnessed in the Damascene state.
On the nineteenth of Shawwal, Hussein Pasha bin Makki, the Governor of the Janissaries [sic: likely implies he had their support or was Governor of Damascus], departed as the Amir of the Noble Hajj, after all the Janissaries and Kapikulu marched with him. Before his departure for Hajj, he had gathered the Aghas of both factions, reconciled them, and wrote a binding document against them in the presence of the Qadi, the Mufti, and the city's notables. Its content was that anyone who transgressed would owe one hundred purses to the Sultan's kitchen and his blood would be shed with impunity. The city calmed down and became like a cup of milk, and not the slightest disturbance occurred.
The peace remained until Sunday, the thirteenth of Dhu al-Hijjah, when a Kurd named Wali arrived. He was from the group of As'ad Pasha bin al-Azm, the current Governor of Aleppo. This Kurdish man had a history of oppression and aggression against the people of Sham. The Janissaries and the commoners rose against him and said, "Kill him!" He fled to the Citadel and sought protection with the Kapikulu, who protected him.
Before the Pasha's departure, the people of Sham had risen with one voice saying, "We do not want a stranger in our town." The Pasha issued a Buyuruldi (decree) for them stating that no stranger/irregular soldier (Gharib Yigit) should remain in Sham. Some left after the Pasha's departure, while others remained. When this man arrived, the commoners and notables were harmed by him. They sent him a message to leave voluntarily to save his blood. He refused to leave Sham, emboldened by the fact that he had taken refuge in the Citadel with the Kapikulu. Immediately, the city closed down, the Janissary Aghas gathered, followed by the commoners, and they rose up fully. The Anatolians (Anatabiya), Kurds, and Dalatiyya gathered. The Kapikulu rose, and the people of al-Amara rose with them. They raided al-Darwishiyya and exchanged fire with the Janissaries until night fell. They attacked the Janissary warehouses filled with timber and burned them; they were worth several purses of money. The Janissaries rose against the people of al-Amara, displacing its inhabitants, women, and children to the Umayyad Mosque, then set fire to it and its markets until it became an open plain.
The situation intensified for the people of al-Amara due to the oppression and aggression of the Janissaries. The boys of al-Haqla from al-Maydan aided them with Jahili zeal, along with some Druze men. They opened the city gates—something never witnessed before now. The Kapikulu attended and returned, charging against the Mosulis, Baghdadis, and Dalatiyya, besieging them, and killing occurred between the two factions.
On the eve of the fourteenth of Dhu al-Hijjah, the moon eclipsed, a terrifying eclipse. On the twenty-second of Dhu al-Hijjah, an earthquake occurred in Damascus, not witnessed for years. It continued for several days and nights. This was after the sun had eclipsed so that stars were seen during the day. Yet this nation would not take heed.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
This sedition lasted for days, fluctuating between peace and rumors, until a council (Diwan) was held by the Aghas and notables of Sham. A decision was made to expel the 'Gharib Yigit' (strangers/mercenaries) from Sham, and that Wali, who was the cause of the sedition, must leave. The Aghas expelled them, accompanied by Ali Effendi al-Muradi to appease the people of the town. They continued escorting them outside the town. The Aghas and Effendi al-Muradi returned, but the fear remained as it was. Then, the people of every neighborhood began keeping watch every night.
The situation remained like this until news reached Sham that those who had left had looted villages, killed souls, and violated harems. The government sent papers to the people of the countryside and villages to kill or expel them. They banded against them and expelled them, but only after they had killed and looted. Then they saw a Kapici (messenger) on their way, so they stripped him and killed some of his group.
The people of Sham remained amidst fear and terrors until Monday, the twenty-seventh of Dhu al-Hijjah, when news reached Sham that Musa Pasha, the Pasha of the Jarda (relief column), upon reaching al-Qatrana, was attacked by Arabs who stripped him and looted the Jarda and everything in it. They even stripped him of his clothes and the ring from his finger, brought him down from his litter, and rode in the litter in his place, taking his drums, standards (Tughs), and cannons. Their leader was called Qa'dan al-Fayez.
Then the group that was in the Jarda scattered. Some returned to Sham, some were cut off in Hauran, some fled to Gaza, some to Jerusalem, and some to Ma'an with the son of Musa Pasha, because it was close to the place where the Jarda was looted. As for the Pasha, he returned to the village of Da'el and stayed there for a number of days. They sent a litter to carry him, but found he had died. They carried him and brought him to Sham. His entry into the town was at the beginning of the night, and the next day they buried him in the tomb of Sidi Khumar, may Allah be pleased with him.

Year 1171
Then the year one thousand one hundred and seventy-one entered, and we are in this state. We ask Allah Almighty to change our condition to the best condition.
In this month, Muharram al-Haram, the erudite scholar, the seal of the Hadith scholars and remnant of the righteous predecessors, Sheikh Salih al-Jinini, the great Muhaddith under the Dome of the Eagle in the Umayyad Mosque, passed away. He had a great funeral and was buried in Bab al-Saghir. May Allah Almighty have mercy on him.
In those days, a second Jarda went out, inferior to the first Jarda. On the twenty-seventh of Muharram, the Jukhadar of Hussein Pasha, the Governor of Sham and Amir al-Hajj, entered, accompanied by three camel riders riding pillion, and with them the brother of Ibn Mudayyan, Sheikh of the Arabs of Hijaz. The people of Sham rejoiced and decorated the markets with lamps. The Kapikulu rose, went out, and fired upon the subjects, causing a strong tremor. Sedition remained in the town between the Janissaries, the Kapikulu, and the Ashraf. The Kapikulu killed about thirty men from the Ashraf, fired upon the Umayyad Mosque, and killed Sheikh Umar Kabab, the mosque's muezzin, as he was descending from the Dhuhr call to prayer. Some children were also killed therein. Chaos ensued in the city markets for days. Then the Aghas and Effendis intervened between them for peace, but they refused. They said to them, "Stop the fighting and wait until Hussein Pasha comes from the Hajj and decides on these rulings." So they stopped the fighting.
The Kapikulu remained in the Citadel, neither moving nor shifting, until Monday, the seventeenth of Safar al-Khayr. While people were disturbed by the delay of the Hajj's arrival and did not know the reason, news came to Sham that the Hajj had been stripped and looted by the Arabs. The Arabs robbed the women and men of their wealth and belongings. The world clamored, people wept, and Sham turned dark.
It reached the people that six letters had come to the Mutasallim (deputy governor) to send reinforcements to the Hajj, but he did not reveal them. The commoners rose and attacked the Mutasallim in the Saraya (palace) and stoned him. The Mawali (judges) and Aghas gathered and called for bringing animals out of the town, and to bring out items, clothes (tailored and sewn), sandals, and slippers, and for men to go out to meet the Hajj. A large crowd went out. Their exit was on Friday, the twenty-first of Safar al-Khayr. This was after they wrote a petition to the State informing them of this situation, and sent to Homs asking Hassan Pasha bin al-Kibrli to come to protect Sham.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On Thursday, the twenty-fifth of Safar al-Khayr, some Janissaries of Sham approached from the direction of the Hajj, accompanied by pilgrims, riding two or three on a beast, in the utmost state of destitution. The crier with them held a white banner, calling out, "This is the banner of the Janissaries." The people clamored with weeping and wailing. Allah is sufficient for us, and He is the best Disposer of affairs. They reported that behind them were a multitude of pilgrims, along with women and girls, including the Queen, barefoot and naked.
Two days later, the Chorbadjis (officers) of the Janissaries approached from Muzayrib, accompanied by the Mashtaji and the Qaftaji, all stripped. On that day, the Janissaries and those remaining of the welcomers returned, accompanied by the Aghas and the Mutasallim Hussein Agha Alay Bey. They reported on the conditions and terrors that befell the pilgrims, men and women, from the evil of the infidel Arabs, without doubt; for these deeds done to the pilgrims are not done even by fire-worshippers. They reported that they would strip a man and search under his armpits, his anus, his mouth, and under his testicles. If they found a man with a large belly or a hernia (Qila), they would slice his belly and rip open his hernia. They inserted their hands into the anuses of men and the private parts of women. A woman would place mud on her front and back to cover her nakedness, but they would uncover it. In short, acts were committed by the Arabs that have never been heard of in ancient times, nor from idolaters or cross-worshippers. None escaped the stripping except those who fled ahead of the Hajj.
The Pasha ordered those around him to loot his treasury, so they looted it. Some survived, some were killed, and some were stripped repeatedly. Then the pilgrims stayed for fourteen days in hunger and thirst, with no water and no provisions. Some died of hunger, thirst, cold, and heat, after some had drunk the urine of others. The oppression of the Arabs was not enough; the oppression of the people of Ma'an was added to it. May Allah be angry with them, curse them, and prepare for them the torment of the Fires.
On the ninth of Rabi' al-Awwal, news came that Hussein Pasha, the Governor of Sham and Amir al-Hajj, was in the city of Gaza and wanted mules, musketeers, and men from Sham. They refused to send him anything of that sort, but rather sent word to him to come to his post because the Kapici with the decree was with them, and to do what he saw as being in the [best] interest.
Days before that, Ahmad Basha bin al-Qaltaqji, the leader of the Zarbawat (thugs) of Sham, had arrived. He had been a fugitive for fourteen years. He came once during As'ad Pasha's absence for Hajj and did what he did, as we mentioned earlier. He came a second time at the beginning of the rule of the mentioned Hussein Pasha, who honored him and gave to him, and he went out with him to Muzayrib, and from there he disappeared. He returned this third time when the sedition occurred in Sham. They forbade them from those actions, but it was of no avail, as previously mentioned.
On Friday, the thirteenth of Rabi' al-Awwal, news reached Damascus that Umar al-Mahamid, the Sheikh of Hauran, found the Mahmal and the Sanjak (flag) with the Arabs. He satisfied them until he redeemed them from them. He found the Mahmalji (Mahmal keeper), the son of the Qabaq Dar, and four or five men in a state of humiliation and brokenness.
On Tuesday, the twenty-sixth of Rabi' al-Awwal, the Mahmal arrived and entered Sham, carried on a camel, covered with its green inner cloth. With it were Muhammad Basha al-Saqbawi, some Druze horsemen, and some Bedouins. They mentioned that they redeemed it from the Arabs for one hundred and seventy piastres.
A Tatar (courier) had arrived in the middle of Rabi' reporting the death of Sultan Uthman, but he did not bring word of whose name the Khutba (sermon) should be given in. So Sham delivered the Khutba without a Sultan's name for two Fridays, until Monday, the first of Rabi' al-Thani, when a Kapici came with the Khutba in the name of Sultan Mustafa Khan. May Allah support him and support the Ottoman dynasty throughout the ages.
Then the pilgrims began arriving in groups. Then the Baltajiyya (axe-men/guards) came, accompanied by the Qadi of Medina and some women. The women who were present that year were counted, reaching five hundred women; no trace of them appeared, along with the Queen, the Sultan's sister.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On the fifth of Rabi' al-Thani, the Kapikulu came out of the Citadel and fired upon the Janissaries. A strong sedition occurred, then the Kapici, the Mawali (judges), and the Aghas reconciled between them, and the fighting ceased.
On the twenty-fifth of Rabi' al-Thani, the Qadi of Medina who came with the pilgrims passed away. Pilgrims began dying one after another, until many of those who were with the Jarda died, because what happened to the Hajj and the Jarda this year is something unheard of, making bodies shiver. To Allah we belong and to Him we return.
Damascus remained without a governor until the end of Rabi' al-Thani, when the news was confirmed, after people's hesitation regarding the matter of Sham's rulers, of the appointment of the Wilaya (governorship) of Sham to His Excellency the Grand Vizier Al-Hajj Abdullah Pasha al-Shataji. His entry into the city of Damascus was in the forenoon of Sunday, the twenty-eighth of Rabi' al-Thani. The notables and dignitaries of Sham went out to meet him. He entered in a procession the likes of which had not been witnessed for others. He entered with a dragging army; he had forty banners of Dalatiyya, fifty banners of Levend, and twenty banners of Arnaut (Albanians).
Then, the next day, he held a Diwan (council) and robed the Mufti, the Qadi, the Naqib of Ashraf, and Sayyid Ali Effendi al-Muradi. The Pasha sent for a group of Janissaries, but they did not respond. So he sent a crier to announce that the people of honor should move away from among the Janissaries. Nothing was seen but the moving of furniture and the emptying of houses and shops.
At the first entry of the Pasha into Sham, the Janissaries gathered, numbering about twenty thousand or more. They displayed courage and lack of fear of him, saying: "We do not account for him, even if his army is double ours."
On the eve of Wednesday, a group of Janissaries gathered in the Suwayqa neighborhood. They began shooting and frightening people, until the people of Sham closed the gates. When day broke, they attacked towards Bab al-Jabiya and shot towards the direction of the Saraya gate. Their matter reached His Excellency the Pasha, Governor of Sham, and he became extremely enraged. The Mawali came and he held a Diwan. Then the Pasha sent demanding the rebellious wretches from them, while the people of honor would remain as they were. The hearts of the Janissaries hardened, they strengthened themselves, and thought they were the victors.
Then the Pasha shouted to his soldiers and rode out himself, seeking the direction of al-Maydan. No one stood before him. He and his army attacked them, and none of them stood firm. He and his army continued striking with the sword until they reached outside Bab Allah. They killed a great multitude of them. Those they did not want to kill, they took and put in chains. The soldiers looted al-Maydan, leaving neither big nor small except killed or captured. They left no house, shop, woman, or child without employing looting, captivity, and violation of honor, including stealing women's jewelry and looting virgin girls, and other things that blind the eyes. They wished for death... [text unclear/corrupt: al-darrar?]. They had never seen such terrible atrocities. The people of Sham suffered a calamity that year not witnessed since the days of Timur (Tamerlane). The outcome of affairs belongs to Allah.
The next day, Thursday, the Pasha's group rose to loot, but he forbade them and ordered the collection of the looted items from the soldiers and others, to be placed in some mosques. He ordered a crier to call out: Whoever has looted property, let him come, identify it, and take it. They took some, but most was lost. As for the Pasha's followers, anyone they saw, they killed him, cut off his head, and left him in the markets, alleys, and houses. They recorded the houses that were looted, and they came to about twenty-four thousand houses. As for the shops, they were countless in number or calculation. Most grievously, the Zawiya of the house of Sheikh Sa'd al-Din al-Jabawi in al-Maydan, where they had placed precious goods, was checked afterwards and absolutely nothing was found in it. The soldiers began pursuing the Janissaries to the villages, hamlets, and deserts, killing and capturing even children and women. Oppression increased in the land, the servants feared, and corruption multiplied. They gathered many heads of Ashraf and commoners and sent them to the State.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
The Pasha ordered the Imams of the neighborhoods to be brought, and ordered them to write that everything looted and robbed had been returned by the Pasha immediately, and not even a cord was lost from anyone. He made them seal this petition with this condition. This was a ploy from him, and they could not disobey his command.
The Pasha's group continued to loot, oppress, transgress, and tyrannize, respecting neither elder nor youth, saying about the people of Sham: "You are all infidels, Christians, and evildoers." He would feed his group nothing but meat, rice, and good bread, until meat became scarce and no bread was found to be eaten. At every bakery were hundreds of hungry people, until most of the town's people became impoverished and began begging from people. Misery increased, and prices rose the rise of a cunning tyrant: a rotl of rice became twenty-four masari, bread the same, dibs (molasses) the same, an ounce of ghee eight masari, an ounce of oil four masari, a ghirara of wheat seventy-three piastres, a ghirara of corn forty-eight, a ghirara of chickpeas sixty piastres, a ghirara of lentils thirty-five, barley fifty, an ounce of sumac four masari, a rotl of onions four masari, and so on by analogy. There is no power or strength except with Allah, the Most High, the Great.
After a number of days, the Pasha cut the expenses of some troops and banners, so they began raiding the villages, looting wealth, honors, and children. Do not ask likewise about the Pasha's soldiers, for they looted orchards, broke trees, and stripped humans. Despite that, the Pasha was not pleased with that; often he treated them with discipline and painful beating, but they did not desist until he started killing some of them. The people of Sham wanted to fight them, but found no one to take their hand, and the notables of Sham did not speak good. The command is for Allah.
In these days, the Pasha exiled the Naqib of Ashraf, Hamza Effendi, to Jerusalem. After a while, a Firman came with a Kapici stating that Abdullah Pasha al-Shataji, Governor of Sham, has delegated authority to do what he wants without consultation. Then he moved for the Dawra (tour) travel. He ordered the extraction of the two cannons at the Citadel gate—they had not been taken out for years and years. He made carriages for them and iron rings; their weight with the wood reached thirty-three qintars. He went out with them seeking the Dawra travel. He made 'Shawahi' (light cannons) like small cannons and mounted them on the backs of camels to turn right and left. Then he ordered the commoners to drag the large cannons; two men died and a group was crushed.
His group imposed money on the neighborhoods and markets, and collected it in haste. When the Pasha went out to the Dawra, his Mutasallim hanged a man. Some of his aides brought a Sharif man and said: "This one shot with the Janissaries." Immediately he ordered him strangled without consulting anyone. One oppresses and this one tyrannizes. Calamity and high prices increased. At every baker's shop sat one of the ruler's aides due to the intense crowding of creatures and the abundance of women and children. You could hear weeping and wailing from them that cuts hearts and livers. The command is for Allah because it is His will.
In those days, news came of the killing of As'ad Pasha bin al-Azm, the former Governor of Sham. Days later, a Kapici came from the State to seal his palace, seize his wealth, seal the houses of all his followers and aides, seize their wealth, and raise them to the Citadel. Distress increased, and matters and terrors occurred in Damascus the likes of which had not happened in past times. Then the followers of Ibn al-Azm As'ad Pasha came, and the Kapici entered the Saraya. He brought out great buried treasures from his palace; lo, they were like hoards deposited therein. They extracted from the ground, walls, ceilings, basins, and even the latrines, dirhams, dinars, precious goods of inestimable value, jewels, and other things known only to Allah Almighty. Judgment is for Allah, the High, the Great.
On Thursday, the fourth of Ramadan, the Pasha came from the Dawra and entered Damascus. On the seventeenth of Shawwal, Abdullah Pasha al-Shataji went out for the Noble Hajj with a great procession and a dragging army.
In that year, Sheikh Ahmad al-Manini al-Hanafi, the preacher of the Umayyad Mosque, passed away, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him.
A great torrent came during the summer forty days (Marba'aniyyah), falling on the village of Jubba near Yabroud. Its descent was at the beginning of the night. It took only an hour to sweep away the village of Jubba completely. Then it passed over Yabroud, covering all the vineyards, demolishing, and killing. Then it reached the village of al-Nabk, roaring in its flow like thunder, destroying much therein. We ask Allah Almighty for kindness in what is destined.

Year 1172

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
Then the year one thousand one hundred and seventy-two entered. Its first Muharram was Tuesday. The Mutasallim in Sham on behalf of Abdullah Pasha was Sulayman Agha, who was reportedly unjust and tyrannical. The arrival of the Hajj Jukhadar was at the end of Muharram al-Haram. The Sardar of the Jarda was Abd al-Rahman Pasha, Pasha of Tripoli.
On the fifth of Safar al-Khayr, the Noble Hajj entered Sham. It was a year of comfort for all pilgrims, due to the fact that the Pasha had killed countless Arabs between the Two Holy Sanctuaries, even killing the Sheikh of the Arabs. The confirmation of Sham came to the Pasha before his arrival in Sham.
The crescent of Ramadan appeared on the eve of Saturday. Cannons were fired in the last third of the night. Flus (coins) were twenty-four for a masriyyah. Eid al-Fitr was confirmed before noon on Sunday; they prayed Eid before noon, and people broke their fast after having been fasting.
On the sixteenth of Shawwal, Al-Hajj Abdullah Pasha al-Shataji headed out as Amir over the Hajj. He was accompanied in the Syrian caravan by Sa'd al-Din Pasha al-Azm as Governor of Jeddah. They took many troops with them, fearing the Arabs due to Abdullah Pasha killing their Sheikh and soldiers.
On the twenty-seventh of Muharram, the Jukhadar of the Noble Hajj arrived and brought good news. Abdullah Pasha al-Shataji dismissed the assistant of the Sharif of Mecca and set up his brother Ja'far in his place. The standing of the Hajj (Arafat) was on Friday. On Saturday, the seventh of Safar, the Noble Hajj entered Damascus, in utmost health.
Then, after the entry of the Hajj, Abdullah Pasha ordered a crier to announce in Sham the lifting of injustice and aggression, and justice from rulers and subjects. He began disguising himself, hiding, and patrolling the streets and alleys of Sham. Comfort was achieved generally by the abolition of evils and the disappearance of people of immorality. The Pasha had cut the expenses of most of his soldiers and ordered their departure from Sham, and that no one should remain in it who has no work or craft. A large crowd departed, and he sent all his camels to Hama. That was from Allah's kindness to Sham and its people, though high prices continued as mentioned.
The Qadi of Sham was a righteous man, so he acted as a Muhtasib (market inspector) and began patrolling the market people himself, calibrating scales, rotls, and ounces. Whoever he found with deficient weights, he beat him soundly on his feet, and whoever he found with full weights, he gave him a silver masriyyah.
Rabi' al-Thani entered, corresponding to Tishrin al-Thani (November), and not a drop of water fell from the sky.
On the eve of Tuesday, the eighth of Rabi' al-Thani of Tishrin al-Thani of this year, in the last third of the night, while muezzins were in the minarets engaging in the 'Murasala' (pre-dawn calling), a light earthquake occurred, followed by a second, then a third. Damascus shook from them a severe shaking. The people of Damascus thought the Resurrection had risen. The tops of most minarets of Sham collapsed, along with many houses, mosques, and countless places. Even the Dome of Victory (Qubbat al-Nasr) atop Mount Qasioun was shaken and half of it thrown down. As for the villages of Sham, there was much destruction, and the dead found under the rubble were uncountable.
On the second night, it shook again at the time the first one shook, then it happened at the time of Fajr prayer and during the day as well. It kept repeating frequently but lighter than the first ones. Fear and calamity increased, and people abandoned their homes, sleeping in alleys, orchards, cemeteries, al-Marja, and the courtyard of the Umayyad Mosque. In this earthquake, the Khan of Qunaytra collapsed on everyone in it; only a few animals and people survived. Likewise, the Khan of Sa'sa'. News arrived in Damascus that some towns and villages collapsed on their inhabitants, so neither they nor their animals survived.
Then on the eve of Tuesday, at the tenth hour of the night, the fifth of Rabi' al-Awwal [sic: likely means Rabi' al-Thani or subsequent month], the sky split, and screaming, rumbling, buzzing, and great terror were heard from it, such that some people of unveiling (Kashf) saw that the ceilings rose, stars appeared, and then the ceilings returned as they were. News arrived that in some lands two mountains closed upon some villages, so the villages disappeared and no trace of them appeared.
On the eve of Friday, the eighteenth of Rabi' al-Awwal [sic], at the time of Isha Adhan, a star/meteor fell from the sky from the west towards the east, illuminating mountains and houses. Then it fell, and a great sound was heard from it, louder than the sound of cannons and thunderbolts.
In the first earthquake, a huge rock fell into the Qanawat river blocking the river. Water was cut off from the town for eleven days. Stone cutters remained cutting it for eleven days. People were in two griefs: the grief of the earthquake and the grief of water scarcity.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
On the eve of Monday, the sixth of Rabi' al-Thani, at the fifth hour, a massive earthquake occurred, greater than the first by degrees. A terrifying tremor accompanied it, bringing down most of the remaining minarets, throwing down the great dome of the Umayyad Mosque, the entire northern arcade, the Kallasa Madrasa, Bab al-Barid, the towers of the Citadel, and most houses of Damascus. What survived falling was scattered apart. Many people were killed, especially in the villages. Crowds moved to the orchards, mountains, cemeteries, and al-Marja. They pitched tents there and in the open fields, sleeping with their families and children. Despite that, the quaking and trembling did not cease, neither night nor day.
Then Abdullah Pasha al-Shataji, Governor of Sham, may Allah Almighty grant him success, ordered a crier to call upon the people to fast for three days and to go out on the fourth day to the Musalla Mosque, for it is famous for the answering of prayers therein. People went out from every deep valley to the Musalla. His Excellency the Vizier went out with them, along with all notables, the Mufti, the Qadi, the scholars, the people of the Tariqas, Sufis, women, and children. They adhered to supplication in the Musalla for three days with clamor, weeping, and humility like the Day of Arafat, rather like the standing of Resurrection. The Most Merciful of the merciful had mercy on them and treated them with kindness and alleviation. The earth began to convulse lightly. People remained fearful in the orchards and open fields until snow and rain fell upon them, and frost occurred, until the earthquake lightened and people returned fearful.
In the middle of Jumada al-Ula, the Qadi arrived in Damascus; his name was Rida Effendi, and he did not move a motionless object. On the eighth of Jumada al-Thani, news appeared in Damascus that Abdullah Pasha al-Shataji, Governor of Sham, was dismissed. On the thirteenth of Jumada al-Thani... And on Thursday, the twenty-second of Jumada al-Thani, Al-Hajj Abdullah Pasha al-Shataji departed for the post of Diyarbakir, as it was said.
On the eve of Monday, the twenty-fifth of Jumada al-Thani, shortly before dawn, a light earthquake occurred in Sham, lighter than the previous earthquakes. Then news spread among people that a massive earthquake would occur. People panicked severely and returned to their previous state of fear, panic, and going out to orchards and cemeteries. We ask Allah Almighty for kindness.
On Monday, the first of blessed Rajab of this year, the Governor of Sham Muhammad Pasha al-Shalik bin Bulad Pasha entered Damascus with a great procession in the forenoon. Notables, dignitaries, Effendis, and Aghas went out to meet him. The Janissaries went out with horses, plated gear, and Davidian armor, and the Kapikulu went out with full gear.
On Saturday, the seventh of Rajab, Nu'man Pasha, Governor of Sidon, entered. He entered in a great procession. The Governor of Sham Muhammad Pasha al-Shalik went out to meet him, accompanied by Effendis, notables, and Aghas. The Governor of Sham hosted him at his place, and lodged every Agha of his Aghas with an Agha of the Pasha's Aghas. He stayed as a guest of the Governor of Sham Muhammad Pasha for three days and four nights, then departed for the place of his job and post in Sidon.
In the middle of the month of Rajab, a great wind came, lasting four days and nights, until it demolished many places. Only a few trees remained. The shaking from earthquakes did not cease night or day, along with the occurrence of high prices even in vegetables. A rotl of bread was five masari, a rotl of eggplant twenty-five masari, a rotl of onions nine masari, a rotl of meat a piastre and a quarter and was not found, a rotl of ghee a piastre and a half and a quarter. The rest as we presented. The historian Al-Budayri said: The poor person did not have even a 'minqir' (small coin), destruction is occurring from earthquakes at every time and moment, and people moved to the land of the peasants. Allah Almighty is the Helper.
On Saturday, the twenty-second of Rajab, a Kapici came from the Sublime State named Sabanikh Zade to inspect the Umayyad Mosque and the building of its dome, its northern side, and its minarets demolished in the earthquakes. With him was a chief architect, laborers, and men to commence the restoration of the mentioned mosque.
On the tenth of Sha'ban, the Governor of Sham Muhammad Pasha al-Shalik marched to the Dawra. He took with him Ahmad Basha bin al-Qaltaqji, along with Muhammad Agha bin Dali and Ibn Bakmaz, who were fugitives with Ibn al-Qaltaqji. When Muhammad Pasha and those with him reached Nablus, Ahmad Basha bin al-Qaltaqji died. He was buried there. His death was by plague, because the beginnings of the plague occurred lightly from the month of Jumada al-Thani, and continued increasing in Rajab and Sha'ban, as well as the existence of high prices as will come.

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
Then the blessed month of Ramadan entered on Thursday. Eid was on Friday. It became an Eid for the dead and the living, but more for the dead. Two days before Eid al-Fitr and two days after it, about a thousand funerals of those who died of plague would go out from every gate of the gates of Damascus every day, God forbid. This is something unheard of since the Plague of Amwas. We ask Allah Almighty for kindness in what the decrees brought. A shortage also occurred in fruit, until an ounce of Janarik (plums) was two masriyyahs, a rotl of apricots twenty-four masari, a rotl of mulberries eight masari, a rotl of apples twenty-four masari, a rotl of pears thirty masari, a rotl of garlic thirty masari, a rotl of onions seven masari, and meat and rice and others as we presented. The matter prolonged, oppression increased, joy vanished, hatred and evils increased, and man did not know where to turn from the intensity of weeping and aversion. To Allah belongs the outcome of affairs.
On Friday, the fifteenth of Shawwal, Muhammad Pasha al-Shalik marched with the Syrian caravan to the Two Noble Sanctuaries. Two days later, the Hajj marched with its equipment. Days later, Uthman Pasha, Governor of the city of Tripoli, Sardar of the Jarda, came. His stay during his residence was in one of the villages without regret or remorse. He marched traveling in Dhu al-Hijjah with the Kikhiyas of Sidon and Nablus.
In the middle of Dhu al-Hijjah, Sheikh Ahmad bin Sawwar, Sheikh of the Mahya, passed away. He was the erudite scholar of his time and age, possessing excessive courage and increasing proficiency in sciences. He had a great funeral and was buried in the cemetery of the grave of Sayyida Atika. After him, his cousin, the noble descendant Sheikh Sulayman, passed away. He used to perform the Mahya in the Umayyad Mosque and in Al-Bazuri Mosque in their neighborhood. In this month also, the erudite scholar, Mufti of the Maliki Masters, Sheikh Yusuf Effendi, passed away. He had a great funeral and was buried in Marj al-Dahdah. May Allah Almighty have mercy on him.

Year 1173
Then the year one thousand one hundred and seventy-three entered. Its first Muharram was Tuesday. Its entry was during intense heat. On the twenty-seventh of Muharram, the Jukhadar of the Noble Hajj arrived, and after him the Writer entered. He reported that this Hajj was extremely comfortable, and that Uthman Pasha, Sardar of the Jarda, performed charitable acts in his gift-giving (Hadiyah) that no one else had done. That is because when they met the Jarda, they found Uthman Pasha, Sardar of the Jarda, had preceded them and was residing in Hediyah waiting for them for eleven days. This never happened to anyone before him. He aided the pilgrims with honor; he fed the hungry, watered the thirsty, mounted the weary, and clothed the naked. Then when his good deeds reached the Sublime State, may the Master protect it from every affliction and calamity, they assigned him the Emirate of Sham, and assigned his son Muhammad Pasha the city of Tripoli.
On Wednesday, the twenty-seventh of Rabi' al-Awwal, a Kapici came with the dismissal of Muhammad Pasha al-Shalik from Sham and assigning it to Uthman Pasha, Sardar of the Jarda. In these days, restoration of the Umayyad Mosque commenced. Architects, carpenters, painters, and stonemasons entered it. They exerted effort in restoring the dome, the eastern side, and what fell of the minarets, and improving it all. It is not opened except at prayer time only. Construction is also busy in the Citadel and its restoration. The restoration of the Citadel was completed in the month of Rajab of the date's year. The restoration of the Umayyad Mosque, the northern side, the dome, restoration of minarets, and its improvement was completed in the month of Ramadan of this year.
Shortly before the month of Rajab, Uthman Pasha marched to the Dawra. He conquered the fortress of Tartura therein. That fortress was in the hand of Zahir Umar, and he killed such. When Uthman Pasha returned from it, Zahir Umar took it by the force of his army without siege.
In this year, rain is abundant, plague is excessive, epidemic exceeds the limit, fruit is very scarce, and high prices are rampant as we mentioned before: a single pomegranate for eight masari, an ounce of apples for seven masari, a rotl of charcoal for fifteen masari, an ounce of ghee for seven masari, an ounce of oil for three masari, and the rest of sustenance on this pattern as we mentioned before. As for Kaymak (clotted cream), a rotl became a riyal. The poor have no state left.
On the twenty-second of Sha'ban of this year, Uthman Pasha came from the Dawra and his conditions were happy. Monday, the blessed Ramadan was confirmed. On the third night of it, while people were in Tarawih prayer, a disturbing earthquake occurred. People cut the Tarawih prayer, fled, trampled one another, their minds were stunned, and their nargiles and some clothes were lost. The second night it happened also with imperceptible tremors.

Year 1174

book_title: Daily Events of Damascus (Hawadith Dimashq al-Yawmiyyah)
text:
Then the year one thousand one hundred and seventy-four entered. Uthman Pasha, Governor of Sham, was in Hajj as its Amir. When the Hajj came, it was reported that this Hajj was among the most blessed of Hajj pilgrimages with prosperity, cheapness, and safety. In that year, a Kapici came ordering the Great Decoration. Uthman Pasha announced that whoever has a game/display, even if of mud and wood, or has knowledge of the arts of physiognomy/magic (Sima) called 'Mala'ib', he has extra honor with me. He spent a portion of money, gave and granted. Parades circulated with types of games, and all industries and crafts operated. They walked in numerous amazing processions; some with weapons, equipment, and luxurious armor, and some with expensive varied clothes. In summary, a decoration occurred the like of which we neither heard nor saw. In that year, Uthman Pasha, Governor of Sham, rode against Sahyun Fortress and conquered it, so the fearful felt safe and tremors decreased. In that year also, news came to Sham of the killing of Abdullah al-Shataji. The State seized his wealth and property, and he went as if he never was.

Year 1175
Then the year one thousand one hundred and seventy-five entered. The Governor of Sham Uthman Pasha was Amir of the Syrian caravan. It was a comfortable Hajj; no distress befell the pilgrims. The standing at Arafat was on Friday. Of strange coincidence is that Uthman Pasha left with the caravan on Friday, stood at Arafat with the Hajj on Friday, and entered Damascus on Friday. During his term, not the slightest disturbance occurred in Sham. He was just to the subjects, and the people of Sham lived a happy life during his term. His Kikhiya was Sulayman Bey, a Mamluk of Sulayman Pasha bin al-Azm. He had endured horrors at the death of the Azm family, so he attained hopes through his patience. In those days, news arrived in Damascus that Sa'd al-Din Pasha bin al-Azm died in Diyarbakir. The order came to seize his money. The State seized his money and took over his property. Trustworthy sources reported that a great amount of money came out of his estate. There is no power or strength except with Allah, the High, the Great.

End of what Al-Budayri mentioned of this history. He abbreviated the events of the last years greatly and added a year by mistake. The correct is what we transcribed. Glory be to Him who is neither heedless nor forgetful.
Ended what we edited by the pen of Muhammad Sa'id Abu Jamal, may Allah improve his condition and destination. That was shortly before noon on Thursday, the twenty-fourth of Ramadan, year 1317.
The book was completed by the hand of the poor servant of noble knowledge Muhammad, son of the late Sheikh Abd al-Qadir al-Majdhub in Maydan al-Hasa in Rajab al-Haram, year 1323.
